title: the sun reader letters boris burka
story: But there has been a groundswell of support for BoJo from ordinary people, fed up at what they see as attacks on freedom of expression and the British way of life.This is what Sun readers have to say about the issue, and Brexit-backer Boris:BORIS Johnson has a dig at burka-wearing Muslims and our elite shake with fear. Don’t they know many thousands of people agree with him? Or do they chose to again ignore the people of this country? Any movement on Boris from the out-of-touch Government will cost them dear.SO Dominic Grieve has threatened to quit Parliament if Boris Johnson became PM. I can think of no better reason for wishing him success.BANG on Boris, about the burka. It being worn in public is scary for children who see it.FREEDOM of speech must not be compromised – and there can be no question of legal action being taken against Boris Johnson, it would be prejudiced by all the attacks on him.THIS week it has been especially hard to be a Muslim woman. Apparently I am not getting the joke, I’m over sensitive, bullied, oppressed, unintegrated, politically motivated, dividing Britain – this list goes on. Perhaps Boris Johnson’s Etonian education did not enable him to understand that in polite society it’s rude to comment with ridicule on the way people dress.ONE thing critics of Boris Johnson’s burka comment overlook is the impact of burka-wearers on those who are deaf and rely on seeing facial expressions, and lip-reading.THE do-gooders complaining about Boris are fanning the flames of hatred by highlighting issues that one wouldn’t really think about. Talk about “integration” appears to be one-sided and discriminatory towards the indigenous people. There is some equilibrium lacking in our “fair, just and equal” land of ours.WHILE I am not sure Boris used a good choice of words likening women in burkas to pillar boxes, he was right that we are frightened by what it represents. We must not destroy Boris, he is good for the people of this country, he cares. He must also be allowed to speak honestly, he has nothing to apologise for.LIGHTEN up, Boris spoke the thoughts of many millions of Brits. If making a gaffe was against the law, Prince Philip could have been banged up in the Tower of London on many occasions during the last 50 years. He wrote the book on it.Boris might have an agenda – what politician doesn’t? – but this mustn’t mean people don’t have a right to voice criticism. Face veils in public, and burkas, are not religious requirements and we must have the right to criticise the wearers.IF I was Boris Johnson, I would agree to attend the diversity training some have suggested . . . and then tear the training session to pieces.I SAW Ranvir Singh berating her guests on morning TV for daring to agree with Boris Johnson? I wonder what her bosses would say if she suggested that she presented her programme wearing a burka. I think we all know the answer to that.PHIL GROWDENNOTHING Theresa May says can be taken at face value. Not so long ago, she promised to stop the witch-hunt of British soldiers, who have seen action and survived in many parts of the world. However, the victimisation of our veterans continues unabated. They are now joined by Boris Johnson, who has frequently ignited the Prime Minister’s wrath and must therefore, be thrown to the wolves.A BUS company has apologised after a driver told a woman to remove her niqab. So would a bank apologise if a security guard asked a man to remove his ski mask?HOW would I stand as a Christian male finding a Muslim lady, dressed in a burka, having a heart attack? Would I be allowed to remove her veil to perform mouth-to-mouth?THE controversy surrounding Boris Johnson’s burka comments has reached ridiculous heights. Police conducting an investigation. Really?IF Theresa May had the guts to ban the burka like a lot of other countries, we might not be having this discussion about what Boris Johnson said.SOMETHING featureless with a rectangular hole in it can resemble a letter box, there’s probably one on your front door, go and have a look. It has also been known for the person inside to be a terrorist, not an innocent woman. Stop being so pathetic, have a sense of humour, act like adultsI READ about a motorcyclist at a filling station having to remove his crash helmet while a woman (who could have been a criminal’s getaway driver) filling up at the pump next to him was wearing a burka. Meanwhile Boris’s remarks are causing hysteria.I HAVE been visiting garden centres and supermarket car parks in my car, which is bedecked with Brexit stickers, asking many people their opinion on the Boris situation. For Boris, I find there is a great deal of love out there. For the Chequers “deal” there is none.IT’S true that Boris Johnson has used strong language but Muslim terrorists are doing far worse things than robbing banks, by committing terrorist atrocities. It would be a sad day when the Muslim community can’t take such a comment, especially when many Muslim women, in my view, do not want this clothing themselves.IT’S confirmed, lunatics are ruining the country. We have the enemy (EU) knocking art the door and all the idiots can find to discuss is Boris Johnson’s perfectly fair comment. If it wasn’t so serious it would be funny. Brexit should be top of the agenda.THERE are easily as many people who agree with BoJo’s comments as those who don’t. So why is it those who don’t will instigate an investigation, leaving those who do without a voice? Even senior Muslims and imams have said that the burka is not a requirement in Islam, so why is it we only tend to listen to those who are offended?Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the last leg ally ross
story: You expect this reaction, obviously, from news organisations who have to fill endless blank hours with something during silly season.The really depressing thing, though, was that a late-night Channel 4 “comedy” show and its presenters were the most outraged of them all.I’m talking, of course, about The Last Leg which, for reasons that still escape me, genuinely fancies itself as one of television’s edgiest and funniest shows.It’s not, clearly. The Last Leg is a television safe space, the authentic voice of the PC establishment and as predictable as the sun rising in the morning.So you knew, long before Friday’s transmission, that they’d be targeting Boris, who is a thousand times funnier and edgier than anyone on this show, in his own way.Nearly a whole working week host Adam Hills and his two mates had to prepare some decent material as well, and this was the best three professional comedians could do.Alex Brooker: “The burka is an item of clothing worn by a human being, the other is a postbox, you f***ing idiot.”Adam Hills: “I’d much rather sit next to a person in burka than a p***k in a suit.”Josh Widdicombe: “Theresa May has only just realised Boris is a t**t, so she should apologise as well.”On and on it went, for 12 minutes and 54 seconds, a figure I mention because I’ve had the clock on this lot, and if you want to know exactly how much of a toss they really give about religious sensitivities then it’s best measured by the fact this series of The Last Leg has devoted just 65 hand-wringing seconds to the anti-Semitic poison infecting the Labour Party.It was crammed hurriedly into the previous episode, which was worth watching just to see Adam Hills describe Corbyn’s handling of this crisis as “a faux pas”, (which isn’t French for “shameful cluster-f***”) and the C4 audience react with evident discomfort because he’d drawn attention to the Labour leader’s failings and, therefore, broken one of comedy’s secret and golden rules.If you doubted these rules exist, incidentally, then ever the virtue-signalling fool, Adam Hills was good enough to spell them out for us on Friday.“Every religion should be open to ridicule . . . but you kind of need to be in the club.“Alex and I can make jokes about disabilities as we’re technically disabled.”Boris, he then explained, can’t make jokes about burkas, ’cos he’s “a white Etonian”, nor could comedy giant Rowan Atkinson defend him, as he was “a white man who lives in Oxford and drives an F1 car”.Even if we ignore the fact he’s assumed that all Muslims are black, something pretty staggering is going on here.For Mary Whitehouse, in all her pearl-clutching glory, never imagined anything quite as Draconian and controlling as this form of satirical Apartheid.Adam Hills has a point, though, when he uses the word “club”. That’s exactly what television comedy has become.A closed, left-wing shop where you don’t even bother joining the audience unless you follow the rigid “Tories and Brexit are evil” party line.This is not creating comedy, it’s policing it, and also the reason why applause has replaced laughter on all those Channel 4 and BBC news satires which have failed to realise there is only one simple rule to be observed when creating these shows: Make it funny, dumbo.I would suggest, at this point, Adam Hills gets off his moral high horse, for once, and gives this “funny” idea a go.But then I could also ask Boris to have a crack at anchoring the British women’s 4x100m relay team to gold at the next Olympics, wearing a burka, and I’d know there was only the remotest chance of one ever happening.Run Boris, run.MEANWHILE, back on Channel 4’s Meet The Drug Lords: Inside The Real Narcos, Jason “Foxy” Fox was with the Colombian navy this week and desperate for a look inside one of the incredible home-made submarines they’d confiscated from drug-smugglers.“Is it locked?”“Yes.”And there’ll be more Bafta-worthy action from Foxy and his forward-planning department this week, I’m sure.EVER since it discovered that Danny Dyer was the rightful heir to the English throne, Who Do You Think You Are? has been struggling to find a purpose, or indeed a celebrity, who could see the bigger picture.That special someone who would acknowledge history’s great events with more than a few “wows” and shrugs and not think their own career made all of their ancestors’ suffering worthwhile.Finally, last night, they found him.Judge Robert Rinder, who as well as having the best brain at ITV (Luna the Labrador off This Morning has the second best) also turns out to be a natural television journalist, telling the story of his maternal great-grandfather, Israel, and his beloved grandfather, Morris, simply, beautifully and without ever letting the details overwhelm him.The former fled revolutionary Latvia at the turn of the last century.The latter’s entire family was wiped out in Treblinka’s gas chambers.Yet he somehow survived the Buchen-wald, Theresienstadt and Schlieben concentration camps and made it to Britain, which offered him salvation, friendship, justice and, above all, a sense that “life is worth living” that has been passed down through eternally grateful generations.It’s a remarkable story, so if you missed it, try to catch tonight’s repeat (BBC1, 11.25pm).SCENES and characters the viewers are unlikely to forget in a hurry on the final episode of BBC2’s wonderful Travels In Trumpland With Ed Balls.First stop, the President’s Mar-a-Lago compound in Florida, where Ed spent the most uncomfortable night of his life, since Strictly, at a one-year-in-office party for Trump, with Toni Holt Kramer and a group of fans who were called The Trumpettes, but could well have been the provisional wing of The Golden Girls.If you thought they were a bit sinister, though, he was then off squirrel hunting in the forests of Georgia with two hillbillies who might not have been plucking banjos but they certainly had the mad cackling laughs and slightly unsettling line in hospitality.“Are you ready to be a man today, Ed?” asked one, as you began to wonder if he could escape with his dignity intact, let alone blend in with the local gene pool.Then he suddenly reappeared – and this was a masterstroke – wearing a Norwich City scarf.Scrub everything I ever said about Ed Balls.The man’s a diplomatic genius.Sent in by Rob Milner, East Yorkshire. title: dad blames size nineteen feet for job woes as he cant find shoes big enough for job interviews
story: David Henderson, 39, can’t find smart black shoes that fit so he turns up to job interviews in his enormous white Adidas trainers — the only footwear he can get into.He says he’s been stuck on benefits for almost a decade as interviewers don’t take him seriously because of his get-up.And to add to his woes, cruel strangers mock him in the street with taunts like “clown shoes” and “Sideshow Bob”.The fed-up former security guard searched Scotland for a cobbler who would make him bespoke shoes but drew a blank.He extended his enquiries across the UK and found a London firm who could help.But to his horror they quoted him a price of £1,500 — far beyond his means as his Universal Credit payment leaves him just £40 to spend each month after bills.A pair of size 19 leather brogues could cost as much as an eye-watering £2,000.Now he’s going public with his problem in the hope it will help him find some decent shoes and get him off the dole.David, from Methil, Fife, said last night: “My feet have just got wider over time and doctors don’t know why.“Employers don’t believe me when I say I can’t buy black shoes but it’s impossible to find affordable ones in my size.“Some interviewers are bemused when I tell them why I’m not wearing black shoes.“Some are surprised and some are sympathetic. But I can tell some of them are thinking ‘are you for real?’“I feel like a bit of a tink turning up to job interviews wearing a tracksuit, T-shirt and trainers — but I would look ridiculous if I was wearing smart clothes and my big white trainers.”David added: “It’s been a total nightmare and very embarrassing. I feel like I have tried everywhere in Scotland but nobody does my size.“And I get people making fun of me when I’m at the bus stop or walking down the street people say ‘Wow. look at him. Are those boats on your feet?’. Others call me ‘banana feet’.It’s demoralising. I think I’d have a job if I had shoes. It brings me down and it’s pretty hurtful.“I just want to get back to work. I can’t be the only person in the UK with size 19 feet.”David, who is 6ft 2in tall and weighs in at 24 stone, has had big feet since he was youngster.When he left school he was a size 16. But he could find shoes that fitted him at the time and worked in retail, cleaning and security jobs through his 20s.But since then his feet have grown three sizes and are almost 12in long and 7in wide. David says he has been turned down by at least ten employers since he last worked.His worried girlfriend Annie Jones, 32, said she hopes he can resolve the situation and land a job.Annie said: “People laugh at him. They point at him and call him names. It’s mean when they call him “clown shoes” and it gets him down.I hope he can get back to work. It would mean a lot to him.”Do you have bigger feet? title: first part time jobs sun writers
story: The number of 16 to 17-year-olds taking part-time jobs has more than halved since 1997, dropping from 42 per cent to 18 per cent. It means young people are missing out on essential skills as they approach adulthood.GRANT ROLLINGS asked five Sun columnists what their first part-time jobs were and the valuable lessons they learned – from being polite to skiving.I ALWAYS had a summer job, usually it meant working full-time hours on my normal Saturday job as holiday cover. This was either in a boutique such as Chelsea Girl or in BHS, where I worked on the sweetie counter.I coped with the boredom by sneakily munching on the best chocolate sweets from the pick-and-mix. I also worked as a waitress in a trendy Glasgow eaterie during the holidays.All of these jobs gave me the most enormous respect for the men and women who toil for long hours, often dealing with unreasonable members of the public for too little pay and not much prospect of promotion.Working in the service industry taught me the power of a disarming smile, and proved that my old granny’s saying that “you get more in life from sugar than vinegar” could not be more true.Grumpy customers demanding refunds and diners moaning that they had been waiting too long for their main course were usually placated with a swift apology and a promise to sort things out.A major restaurant blunder could often be smoothed over with a free coffee or pudding.MY favourite summer job came in 1977. I was a traffic enumerator for Middlesbrough Council. That meant I spent all day counting cars. All the way up one side of Linthorpe Road, all the way back down the other.I had to write down all the number plates. In the end, I got a bit bored and spent the time hanging out at my mate’s T-shirt shop or Fearnley Records and made the numbers up, always remembering to have them end in the local codes of HN or (I think) XG. I hope the council thought it worthwhile.It was better than the glue factory, where I’d been very briefly working on a weighbridge. Foreman pressed a button and this vast door opened and thousands of rotting animal carcasses fell out. I can still smell it now, all these years later. I passed out — soft lad, you see.Or there was working the nightshift pricing cans of food and stuff in Hintons, the local convenience store. Every time I turned up, the manager would say, ‘Here he is, the poor man’s Rod Stewart’.A friend of mine, Mark, had a much better summer job.He was a Club 18-30 holiday rep. He shagged 21 girls in 25 days, which gave me my first story to sell to the national newspapers.MY first holiday job was in the summer of 1985 when I was 16 years old. I had already been turned down from working at Waitrose in Enfield Town on the basis I was “too glamorous”.That just goes to show how far we have come in such a short time. I have never set foot in a Waitrose since that day because I was beyond furious. Anyway, the job I did get was working in a hairdresser’s on Goodge Street in London.My journey involved three changes and about 14 stops every day. The job was meant to be answering the phone, sweeping up and generally helping out, but before the end of the first week I was running the till, the appointment system, cashing up and generally managing the place.The only thing I could not do was cut hair, but that didn’t stop me cutting my friends’ hair — with very mixed results, more bad than good — on the basis I worked in a hairdresser’s so they thought I should. I remember the liberating feeling of earning my own money, it gave me the greatest sense of independence, self-esteem and self-belief.I worked out I was actually good in a work environment, talking to people — for example, talking women into perms they didn’t want — being responsible, handling money and making a difference to my employer.The biggest transition we make in our lives is leaving education to go into the workplace, and summer jobs prepare you for this.I HAD dozens of summer jobs, from working as a scaffolder’s mate with a convicted murderer, who kept a pistol in the glove compartment of his Ford Escort, to donning a white suit and Geiger counter to carry out maintenance on the core of the main reactor at a nuclear power station.I learned a hundred things from each and every job, but it was working as a grocery assistant at my local supermarket that had the most impact.My best friend and I both got jobs there at the same time. He was a star performer at school, a brilliant academic, but he couldn’t take the pace and got fired after a couple of months.It was incredibly hard, repetitive work.The manager was an ex-Army major — very strict on haircuts, discipline and stealing.There was always the prospect of the Tannoy announcement “customer service one hundred”, which was code for a shoplifter having been spotted.All the male floor staff were required to assemble at till number one to tackle the suspect, who would sometimes become violent.I was much happier making the cheese look pretty and eventually became the ruler of the entire soft dairy aisle — a project I’m still working on.I WAS 13 in Brownes Wine bar, Stafford Street, Derby, summer 1987, some years before it burned down in mysterious circumstances (has a bar ever burnt down innocently?). I was chief bottler-up.This involved the soul-sapping exercise of sifting through bins taller than me for all the recyclable bottles from the previous night’s festivities and putting them in their correct crates. This took all morning and you ended up cut to shreds and stinking of Britvic and Schlitz.I was then asked to be the cook — this involved microwaving lasagne for drunk people. I was paid the princely sum of £3 per hour. I realised how crap this was, so one scorching Saturday I nicked the shampoo that came with my dad’s company car and took advantage of the sketchy Eighties attitude to drink-driving and washed all the customers’ cars in the car park for a fiver a pop.I literally cleaned up. It was the greatest Dragons’ Den moment I’ve ever had. I waxed on and off all day, rinsing my dad of his prized BMW product. He arrived to pick me up and I was minted. A 13-year-old with £64 in his pocket. That coveted Swatch would finally be mine.He then told me the dog had been run over, so that’s another memory ruined.Thanks for reminding me.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: corbyn is unfit to be labour leader
story: His entire political career has been spent in close company with anti- Semites, terrorist sympathisers and extremists.So it shouldn’t be a surprise that he was pictured appearing to pay his respects to Black September, the terror group which murdered 11 Israelis and one German policeman at the Munich Olympics.That’s a group that not only killed in cold blood but tortured and brutalised their victims too.It is genuinely shocking that the Leader of the Opposition is so willing to lie about it. To say that he was “present but not involved” is an insult to voters’ intelligence when photographs show him holding a wreath and gurning for a nearby camera.To allow his press office to say the widows of those murdered in Munich were being “misled” is, even among the many shameful episodes we’ve seen since he became Labour leader three hate-filled years ago, disgraceful.The most vital qualification for power in this country must be integrity. And Jeremy Corbyn has demonstrated this week that he has absolutely none of it.But for all of the shame that he brings upon Labour, it is nothing compared to the spinelessness of the party’s “moderate” MPs whose opposition to Corbyn extends not much further than wishy-washy tweets.“Present but not involved” isn’t an excuse for Corbyn but nor is it for the cowards on Labour’s backbenches.Corbyn cannot be allowed near government. But the rest of the party has lost the public’s faith too.TOMORROW, official figures are likely to suggest that train fares will go up by another 3.5 per cent in January.If you’re a commuter who has put up with delayed and cancelled trains, you’ll be wondering what you’re paying for.After a disastrous year, there is no other industry that would turn round and ask customers for even more.The failure of the Government to take responsibility, blaming unions or claiming the cash is for “investment”, is simply not good enough. It’s the same as last year’s excuse.It is time for a radical overhaul — but that does not mean nationalisation. Far from it. Our railways need MORE private sector involvement.The hybrid system we have, in which private operators rely on publicly owned tracks and have their fares regulated by government, has led us into the worst of both worlds.Transport supremo Chris Grayling needs to take on the unions once and for all. And he needs to introduce real competition on the railways, giving operators far more freedom.Commuters deserve better than finger-pointing and higher fares.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brit gran not first complain spanish tourists in benidorm
story: Dozens of other disgusted holidaymakers claimed Hotel Poseidon Playa was teeming with rude Spanish families taking over.Freda Jackson, 81, said she was left in tears at the end of her two-week holiday to the tourist hotspot.The grandmother to six, from Blackburn, Lancs., said: The hotel was full of Spanish holidaymakers and they really got on our nerves because they were just so rude.One evening a Spanish guy nearly knocked me flying and he just walked off without even apologising.The entertainment in the hotel was all focused and catered for the Spanish - why cant the Spanish go somewhere else for their holidays?And remarkably, the shocking TripAdvisor reviews now show the retired care assistant is not alone in her complaints.Brit claimed the Spanish had invaded and taken over the three-star hotel.One woman, of Stoke-on-Trent, Staffs., even branded her trip the worst holiday shed ever had.In her rant, she said: No complaints of staff or the hotel, just the very rude ignorant pushy Spanish that invaded the hotel.We did read up on reviews that said there were few Spanish , but not so many they overtook the hotel.Evening entertainment 99 per cent Spanish, couldnt get on dance for them :( 99 per cent Spanish music, they all grouped together with the chairs and tables, we didnt dare move as they would have wiped ours too (sic).But the hotel replied: Thank you for the time you used to write your review and for your words about our hotel and staff.We regret that our entertainment was not to your liking. It is usually very well rated by the most Customers (any nationality).Our daily entertainment includes activities like GAP, games, power dance, latin dance, laugh therapy, English petanque, etc. and our night entertainment includes shows, live music, contests, cabaret, etc.And another guest, from Sunderland, Tyne and Wear, took to the site to allege that Spaniards at the hotel gave English guests filthy looks.Lovely clean hotel, pricey bar for drinks, terrible for the Spanish giving you filthy looks soon as they realise your English (sic)!Another woman wrote: It was all in Spanish, I know it is in Spain but everything was catered for the Spanish, the food, the music.If you where an OAP and Spanish you would have had a ball, hotels I know cater for all as it is for tourists all over the world not just Spanish (sic).Other tourists moaned the Spanish were rude and the entertainment was in Spanish.However, the majority of comments on the site are positive.And in response to one unhappy guest, the manager of Hotel Poseidon Playa wrote: We have 25 international channels in our TV, not just one in English and the rest in Spanish.Yes, we have some traditional Spanish food in our menu, as an extra plate, but we also have different meats, fish, rices, vegetables, pies, pasta, paella.... Also Shepherds Pie and Yorkshire Pudding on some days, so plenty of international choice.For breakfast you will find, bacon, sausages, fried eggs, scrambled eggs, boiled eggs, fresh fruits, pastries, yougurts, pancakes, omelletes... A choice for everyone. We also have tea and a selection of infusions.During the month of March, we have catered a lot of other nationalities, not just Spanish, and in every department there is more than two workers that speak very fluent English.Freda, who suffers from mobility issues, had saved up her pension for the £1,133 Thomas Cook trip with her 61-year-old pal.A spokesman for the holiday operator said: Due to a system error Ms Jackson was not informed of a change to her flights until six days before departure.We are very sorry for the inconvenience this caused and are investigating to make sure it doesn’t happen again.We have offered Ms Jackson and her travel companion a gesture of goodwill to try and put things right which we hope she will accept.

title: 7 summer activities you can
story: Advertorial7 summer activities you can do with the kids without breaking the bankThe summer holiday can be costly, so here are some ideas of low-cost family activities to enjoy togetherShare&nbspByHolly Thatcher15:11, 6 AUG 2018Updated16:22, 13 AUG 2018AdvertorialGet daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe summer holidays are a great time to create wonderful memories with the family. The good news is that spending quality time with the ones you love doesn’t have to be expensive. Here are some suggestions for activities the family will love without costing the Earth… 1. Pimp an old bike A bike ride is a fantastic way to spend time with the kids, and it can be combined with a low-cost picnic for an even nicer day. Anyone with small people in their lives will vouch for the fact that they don’t stay small for long. The advantage? They quickly outgrow their bikes, meaning there’s likely to be plenty of friends and family with once-loved models gathering dust in the garage or shed.  If your child doesn’t have a bike, speak to friends, neighbours – or check out Freecycle . Once you’ve got your hands on some pre-loved wheels, take your bike to Halfords for a Free Bike Check . In-store experts will check tyre pressure, brakes and gears. If they spot anything that needs attention, they can fix it too. If you'd prefer to go new than second hand, Halfords currently has a range of kids' bikes at up to 30% off - like the BMX-style Apollo Ace Kids' Bike, &pound63 (save &pound27), which is suitable for ages three to 11 - depending on the model.  2. Get them growing   Kids love getting their hands dirty – and if you have a garden or access to an allotment then you can join forces to tackle the weeds and grow some wonderful flowers, fruit and vegetables. Reward the littl’un who pulls up the most weeds, hold a sunflower growing competition, or see who can coax the biggest marrow from the soil. You can encourage kids to help by letting them choose their own plants: fruits like strawberries and tomatoes are also fun and reasonably simple to grow – they also have a tasty reward at the end! 3. Make some real lemonade  Making real lemonade is simple to do, inexpensive and unbeatable on a warm day. Gather some lemons, sugar and water (you’ll need roughly 140g of caster sugar and 1 litre of water for every three lemons).  Once it's ready, enjoy in the shade of the Halfords 250 Fully Waterproof Gazebo, &pound39 (save &pound11) - perfect for covering a lemonade stand or an outdoor play area. 4. Go hunting for bats   Bats are glorious creatures, and the summer months are a good time to get out and spot them. As the sun sets you can usually spot these flying mammals darting about in the sky. Their erratic flight patterns mean they're easy to distinguish from birds, and keeping an eye out for them is a great way to spend an evening. You can also head to your local park with an evening picnic – use the Halfords Coolbag Trolley , &pound15 (half price), to get your food there with minimal carrying effort. As it gets dark, lie back on a Halfords XL Waterproof Picnic Blanket,&pound10 (half price), and spot the sonar-equipped mosquito-munchers in action.  Or, if you're looking to go further afield, why not take the Urban Escape 6 Person Vis A Vis Tent along and make it an overnight trip. It's currently half price at just &pound125. Take some facts about bats with you too, so the little ones will learn about one of nature's most misunderstood creatures. For example, bats can – apparently – consume up to 1,200 mosquitos per hour and will sometimes eat their own bodyweight in insects in a single night. You'll find loads of information and details about organised Bat Walks on the Bat Conservation Trust's website. 5. Get them stargazing Those summer nights are ideal for checking out the cosmos. The lack of clouds means uninterrupted views of the universe and the hot weather means you'll get a nice warm evening to gaze into space. You don't need special equipment for basic stargazing. Apps for your phone will tell you what's visible, and guide you to interesting stars and planets, as well as giving you the names of constellations. The Moon often looks stunning, and it's also possible to spot Jupiter and Saturn in the night sky using the naked eye. If you have a decent pair of binoculars you can also spot nebulae and get a great view of our solar system. The Moon, in particular, is a great thing to examine with binoculars.  An Urban Escape King Size Moon Chair , &pound30 (half price), is the perfect spot (with the perfect name) for checking out the cosmos. If you get the bug, check out your local stargazing club. Often you'd be expected to take your own telescope but many would be thrilled to let you experience the night sky through their equipment – check the internet and don't be afraid to fire off an email. 6. Watch a movie in the moonlight   Across the country there are multiple places to catch a movie in the great outdoors. Search hard enough and you might even find free outdoor movies near you. Taking in a movie on the big screen outdoors can be a great way to spend time with the family. Pack yourselves a nice supper in the Summerhouse Seville 4 Person Wicker Picnic Basket, &pound69.99 - and don’t forget to include the popcorn! 7. Take a low-cost road trip

title: jeremy corbyn says present palestinian
story: NewsBenjamin Netanyahu slams Jeremy Corbyn over claims he laid wreath at terrorists' gravesHe said a wreath was laid for Palestinian activists thought to be behind the massacre of Israeli athletes at the 1972 Munich Olympics, but he does not 'think' he was involvedShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter14:38, 13 AUG 2018Updated20:18, 13 AUG 2018NewsCorbyn says he was present for the wreath laying, but does not 'think' he was involved (Image: Facebook)Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has slammed Jeremy Corbyn over claims he laid a wreath at the graves of Palestinians suspected of being behind the Munich Olympics Massacre. The Labour admitted he was present at a wreath-laying ceremony during a visit to the Palestinian Martyrs’ Cemetery in Tunisia in 2014. But he said he does not “think” he was involved in the ceremony, and denied he was there to pay respects to terror suspects. Mr Corbyn faced criticism after photographs emerged which appeared to show him posing with a wreath near the graves of senior members of the Palestinian Liberation Organisation (PLO), who were accused of founding Black September - the terror group who masterminded the attack.  A source close to Mr Corbyn said he had visited the cemetery pay respects to the 47 victims of a 1985 Israeli air strike on the Palestine Liberation Organisation (PLO) offices in Tunis, which is marked with a stone memorial. But pictures appear to show Mr Corbyn around 15 feet away near the graves of PLO second-in-command Salah Khalaf and Atef Bseiso, the group’s intelligence chief. Both men were accused of being involved in planning the Munich massacre. Israeli secret service Mossad was accused of gunning downthe two men - Khalaf in Tunis in 1991 and Bseiso in Paris in 1992 Asked about the visit last night, Mr Corbyn said: “A wreath was indeed laid by some of those who attended conference to those that were killed in Paris in 1992. I was present when it was laid. I don't think I was actually involved in it. I was there because I wanted to see a fitting memorial to everyone who has died in every terrorist incident everywhere because we have to end it. You cannot pursue peace by a cycle of violence. The only way you pursue peace is a cycle of dialogue. Mr Netanyahu wrote on Twitter: “The laying of a wreath by Jeremy Corbyn on the graves of the terrorist who perpetrated the Munich massacre and his comparison of Israel to the Nazis deserves unequivocal condemnation from everyone - left, right and everything in between.

title: mad boris tea party tells
story: NewsopinionThe Mad Boris tea party tells us all we need to know about this shabby charlatanGiving tea to journalists is an old trick - and Boris did it badlyShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist13:26, 13 AUG 2018Updated14:07, 13 AUG 2018NewsopinionGet politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email When grizzled old hacks gather to share stories of scandals past, it is not unknown for them to speak fondly of Mary Archer.  The fragrant wife of convicted perjurer and former Tory deputy chairman Sir Jeffrey is still beloved, three decades later, for bringing a cup of tea to the press pack gathered outside their Cambridgeshire vicarage during one of her husband's many scandals. That someone hounded and pursued by the forces of Fleet Street should be so hospitable was considered remarkable, even heroic. It bought her considerable goodwill, not just because a small village in Cambridgeshire is bereft of places to buy tea but also because, when on a job miles from anywhere, bored and stood outside in all weathers, it is a civilising pleasure to drink from china rather than Styrofoam. It humanises those on all sides - if hunter and hunted both drink tea, they think the other can't be all bad. It is a moment of peace and acknowledgement of the other's tribulations, like Christmas Day football between enemies in World War One. It doesn't end the war, but it's a nice thought.  In 2007, footballer Teddy Sheringham performed the same feat when his then-girlfriend Danielle Lloyd was in the Celebrity Big Brother house and embroiled in a race row with Jade Goody and Shilpa Shetty.  Only he did it half-naked.   And so it was that this weekend former Foreign Secretary and habitual-utterer-of-nasty-things Boris Johnson 'did a Mary', as it is known by some, and produced a tray of tea for the photographers gathered outside his country home in Oxfordshire.  There is a lot that can be gleaned from a person's tea habits, and even more from a tray produced for others. While gazing enviously at Teddy's abdomen, you will I am sure have noticed he carried a set of matching mugs, minimalist aluminium sugar caddy, and a 2-pint bottle of semi-skimmed milk, on a pleasingly biscuit-coloured wooden tray. All very stripped-down and simple. You get the impression this is a man who does not like mess, and treats strangers with the same high standards he expects in his own life. Two pints tells you he lives alone, and frugally. The tray says his kitchen is pristine, and his fingernails clean.  I'm not sure what Mary's tea tray looked like - but there are rumours it involved proper cups with saucers. AND BISCUITS.  Boris did not do that. In fact, Boris could not have made more of a cock-up of it if he tried.  The tray contains a hotch-potch of thick clay mugs. One came free with an Easter egg. One looks like it usually has toothbrushes in it. Another bears a corporate logo, and one appears to be from a Battersea Power Station sponsorship programme.  They are, in short, the mugs you make the staff drink from. Mugs that don't matter.  And no sugar bowl for the snappers. No. A half-open packet of granulated, no doubt with a used spoon wedged in it.  This is a tray that screams YOU'RE ALL PEASANTS, NOW SAY THANK YOU.   And bear in mind, this is the fellow's second home. He's a multi-millionaire. There's bound to be nice mugs and a milk jug in that farmhouse somewhere, he just hasn't bothered to produce them. The milk is truly boggling. The man has four children and a wife. The children are grown up, but even if they weren't at home there's a minimum of two adults there for the whole weekend, and possibly friends and political advisers visiting. A single pint of milk wouldn't last an afternoon, so anyone sane would buy a 4-pinter on the trip down from London. Which leads me to the uncomfortable conclusion that Boris is either so stupid he bought several, more expensive 1-pint bottles, or that he keeps an old 1-pinter to use as a milk jug. And that's just skanky.  He is the antithesis of Teddy Sheringham. This is a tea boy who leaves you wondering whether the mugs were washed first, and what in. His fingernails, were they to be inspected, would almost certainly contain traces of the past week's bogeys. Boris did admirably in refusing to answer questions, and declaring himself on a humanitarian mission because you have been here all day and you've been incredibly patient. But if the purpose of his jaunt down the garden path was to buy goodwill, it failed for three simple reasons.  The first is that tea is fundamentally about good manners. The same rituals and purpose apply whether in a Japanese tea ceremony or a truckers' roadside caff. Boris' tray displays an impolite lack of consideration, and would be looked at aghast were he to offer such a thing at an official reception, to his in-laws, or to Theresa May.  But seeing as Boris is in his current disciplinary hate-crime pickle because he likened veiled Muslim women to letterboxes, manners are presumably something he lacks on a grand scale.  The second is that, if this tray is really the best he could muster, he must surely have seen that it needed adornment of some kind. Half a packet of Digestives, perhaps, or a handful of Penguins. Anything. Instead, it's as graceless as his writing. And third is the basic rule that anyone volunteering for a tea run is usually doing it to be nice - to repay an earlier run done by a colleague, to suck up to someone, or to apologise for past wrongs.  In Boris' case, he's doing it to pretend to be nice. A bit like when he and Gideon Osborne sat down with some Transport for London workers in hi-vis jackets, and tried for a photo that didn't make them look like Buller boys talking to daddy's horse valet.   In short, the best that Boris could do, when caught in a jam of his own making and confronted by journalists, was to attempt deflection with a half-hearted tea round that did little more than belittle the people he delivered it to. The proof is in the pudding with these things, and those journalists will no sooner give him an easier ride tomorrow than he will deliver them a tea pot and the family china.  Not just because since Boris' column last week there has been an increase in reported hate incidents against women wearing a face veil, but because journalists know and loathe Boris of old.  He's been fired for making up quotes from his own godfather, promised to use journalistic means to track down the address of someone a mate wanted beaten up, and has not only used his pen to foment racism but boasted of the &pound250,000 he is reportedly paid for doing it.

title: baby who stopped breathing 90
story: NewsBaby who stopped breathing 90 minutes after birth saved after doctors refrigerate body down to FOUR degreesSimon Meanwell was given a second chance at life by medical staff who wrapped him in a cool blanketShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByLaura Forsyth16:59, 13 AUG 2018Updated17:04, 13 AUG 2018NewsNorfolk and Norwich University Hospital took Simon's temperature down by 4C and brought him back to life (Image: MEANWELL FAMILY/ WESSEX NEWS AGE)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A newborn baby's life was saved after his temperature was brought down to four degrees thanks to a special blanket.   Simon Meanwell was brought back to life by medical staff after being placed on pioneering cool blanket.  The tot, who is now aged six-months, stopped breathing 90 minutes after being born, but was saved by the medical equivalent of being refrigerated. As a way of showing their gratitude his parents, James and Helen, are raising money for the facilities and teams that saved their little boy. It initially took three attempts at resuscitation for Simon's tiny lungs to work on their own again. But it was a little known therapy designed to cool the body temperature of babies down which stopped him having seizures, saved his life, and boosted his chances of growing up without disabilities.  Simon was born at Peterborough Hospital and everything initially seemed to go smoothly. But soon Mr and Mrs Meanwell's newborn son stopped breathing and medics rushed to give him CPR. Mr Meanwell, 41 and from Colsterworth, Lincolnshire, said: He was absolutely fine when he was born but then he stopped breathing. It took six minutes to get his heart started. Simon's condition was so serious he needed to be transferred to the nearest specialist centre, the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) in Norwich. Mr Meanwell, who works at a company which imports quad bikes, said: The vehicle is basically a NICU in the back of an ambulance. As soon as they had resuscitated him they started what they call a cooling process, which lasts for 72 hours. The treatment, known as cooling therapy, is relatively new and is used on babies who are seriously deprived of oxygen during or shortly after birth to help prevent brain injury.  It involves putting the baby on a waterproof blanket which contains cool circulating water to lower the body temperature to 33C for 72 hours, before allowing it to return to normal. Until 2014 there was no approved treatment to help reduce the aftershocks of low oxygen at birth but researchers think the therapy works by slowing the production of harmful substances in the brain and the rate of brain cell death. The Meanwells stayed at the N&ampN for two weeks, where they described the care and support as outstanding, before being allowed back to Peterborough. In total Simon was in hospital for a month. Mr Meanwell said: The first couple of days we were just totally in shock. It was very upsetting.

title: british teenage girl zante gets
story: NewsBrit teen in Zante left with Friday Night Dinner quote scarred on arm after henna tattoo goes badly wrongBeth Fitzsimmons was on the Greek island when she and eight pals opted to get 'shalom Jackie' written in hennaShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByDave Burke15:54, 13 AUG 2018Updated23:50, 13 AUG 2018NewsBeth Fitzsimmons, 18, who got herself the henna tattoo while holidaying on the Greek island of Zante (Image: Mercury Press &amp Media)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA teenager has been left with a phrase from popular TV show Friday Night Dinner scarred onto her arm after a holiday tattoo went badly wrong. Beth Fitzsimmons was on the Greek island of Zante when she and eight pals decided to get the words 'shalom Jackie' written on their arms. But the henna tattoo - which cost five euros - left her with a burning sensation on her arms, and could now take six months to heal. The 19-year-old had an allergic reaction to an ingredient in the black henna, which can contain high levels of toxic chemical paraphenylenediamine (PPD). She chose the words 'shalom Jackie' because people on the holiday kept shouting it and she and her friends found it amusing.  Despite worrying her parents, Beth says nothing was wrong with the tattoo until the eight day, when it started itching and she had a burning sensation. Beth, from Southwell, Nottinghamshire, said: It was one of those phrases that people were just shouting. My friends and I thought it was really funny so on the third night of the holiday after going out we decided to get it done. We were on a night out but I don't really drink so I was sober when I did it.  It was done by a random family in the street. The mum and dad were doing them. We woke up the next day and thought it was hilarious. We sent pictures to our parents and and they were like 'that better not be permanent'. It was absolutely fine until about eight days later then it was so itchy and it felt like it was burning. It was so red. It was all raised up. Now it looks a bit like eczema and is very dry.  I went to the pharmacy about a week after I got back home and they didn't have a clue. That was on a Thursday and they said if it was still there on Sunday go to the walk-in centre. I thought that was a bit extreme so I went to the doctor on the Monday. I said to them that I was probably overreacting but I needed to know if it was going to scar permanently because when I looked it up it said you needed to be treated for chemical burns. I was so worried it would scar me forever. The para-phenylenediamine chemical in black henna is also used in hair dyes and not in brown or other coloured henna. It can cause blistering of the skin, painful burns and can lead to scarring as well as leaving someone with a lifelong sensitivity to it which increases the risk of severe allergic reaction when using hair dyes in the future. When she returned to the pharmacist to collect her prescription, Beth was warned because of the chemical she would no longer be able to dye her hair.

title: british woman 81 claims benidorm
story: NewsBritish tourist moans her Benidorm holiday was ruined by 'too many Spanish people'Freda Jackson, 81, said she cried at the end of her two-week trip to the popular holiday destination through travel operator Thomas Cook in May this yearShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByTom Kershaw10:41, 13 AUG 2018Updated17:04, 13 AUG 2018NewsFreda Jackson, 81, said that Spanish people should go somewhere else for their holidays (Image: Lancashire  / SWNS)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA British woman has claimed her holiday to Benidorm was ruined because her hotel had 'too many Spaniards in it' Freda Jackson, 81, said that Spanish people should go somewhere else for their holidays and she cried at the end of her two-week trip. The pensioner, who suffers from mobility issues, says her accommodation was teeming with 'rude' native Spaniards - who nearly knocked her over on one occasion. Retired care assistant Freda said: The hotel was full of Spanish holidaymakers and they really got on our nerves because they were just so rude. One evening a Spanish guy nearly knocked me flying and he just walked off without even apologising. The entertainment in the hotel was all focused and catered for the Spanish - why can't the Spanish go somewhere else for their holidays?  Freda had booked to stay at the Poseidon Playa, located on the outskirts of Benidorm in south east Spain, with a friend in April 2017. The pensioner says the travel operator Thomas Cook had even recommended the hotel and despite her request for flat ground access, it was located on a slope instead. Grandmother-of-six Freda and her 61-year-old friend paid a total of &pound1,133 for the holiday and have demanded a full refund or a free trip. Freda, who lives in Blackburn, Lancashire, said: I have never complained about a holiday before - but this one was a disaster from start to finish.  My friend and I paid for it from our pensions and it was a struggle trying to fund it over 12 months and the holiday was totally ruined - I cried after. We wanted to go somewhere on flat ground and not in the hills because we have mobility issues. To top it off once we got to reception they told us we had been put on the 14th floor, thankfully we were moved to the second floor, and that it was 42 steps down to the hotel's swimming pool. The pair travelled 1,500 miles from Manchester Airport to Alicante on May 10, after not being notified by Thomas Cook that the dates of their flights had changed. Freda, who has previously visited Greece, Turkey, Portugal and Tenerife, claims Thomas Cook 'mis-sold' and 'ruined' her dream holiday.  She said there were no reps on the holiday who they could complain to about the trip - so instead Ms Jackson submitted a letter of complaint to Thomas Cook. Thomas Cook bosses initially offered Freda and her friend a &pound75 holiday voucher as compensation for the 'disappointing' trip abroad. But after declining the initial 'goodwill gesture' made by the travel company, they made an improved offer of &pound566 to be split between Freda and her friend. title: devastated couple try arrange wedding
story: NewsDevastated couple try to arrange wedding in a week after groom given crushing cancer diagnosisSharon Marsden and Andy McDonald, from Coventry, had been planning on getting married next year when Andy was told he had just weeks to live after lung cancer had spread to his liver and spineShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByElis Sandford22:29, 13 AUG 2018Updated22:36, 13 AUG 2018NewsSharon Marsden and Andy McDonald with their two children (Image: Coventry  WS)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA devastated couple are trying to arrange their wedding in just seven days after the groom was given a crushing cancer diagnosis Sharon Marsden and Andy McDonald from Coventry had been planning on getting married next year, when Andy was told he had just weeks to live. The 47-year-old has suffered from a number of health issues, and had tests after suffering what was thought to be a chest infection in December. But it turned out to be lung cancer and Andy quickly underwent an aggressive course of chemotherapy and radiotherapy, reports Coventry Live . Though recently it was discovered that the cancer had left Andy's lung, it had sadly spread to his liver and spine - and he was given just weeks to live. Sharon and Andy were planning on getting married next year, when Andy was better. But with the tragic news, they have had to have a rethink. And the couple, who have two young children, are trying to organise a wedding - in just one week's time.  On August 20, the couple are set to tie the knot, but they need some help to make the day extra special. Sharon said: We're getting married at Coventry Registry Office, and we're having the reception at Wyken Working Men's Club. We were going to get married next year when Andy was better, but that changed when he was given about two months to live. So we're trying to raise money now to make the day extra special, to hire a DJ, get some flowers, that sort of thing. We have also set up a fundraiser for our reception and honeymoon in the UK. Sharon set up a fundraiser on Facebook, with the hope of raising &pound1,000. Remarkably, in just seven days, she has raised &pound2,090.

title: half brits no idea how
story: NewsHalf of Brits have NO idea how much water they should be drinking each day despite massive heatwaveThe heatwave apparently hasn't had as much of an affect on people's drinking as you might thinkShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByMirror16:48, 13 AUG 2018Updated17:01, 13 AUG 2018News (Image: Digital Vision)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailDespite the recent heatwave, half of British people have no idea how much water they should drink each day, new research has revealed. A third of people admit they don't keep themselves properly hydrated in the heat, despite soaring temperatures over the last couple of months, while a quarter have struggled to increase their intake of fluids over the summer. The research, commissioned by British Summer Fruits, also showed that 51% rarely drink water unless it's mixed with something else, such as squash.  British Summer Fruits, who supply 95 per cent of berries to UK supermarkets, commissioned the research of 2,000 UK adults and found some go as long as seven days without having a glass of water. Dr Emma Derbyshire, Public Health Nutritionist and spokeswoman for British Summer Fruits, said: “Water is the single most important macronutrient to consume to stay hydrated, especially in this hot weather. “Water is energy, calorie and sugar free so can help you to stay hydrated without providing surpluses of these.” The research also found nine in 10 typically add squash or cordial to sweeten plain water. And just one in 10 opt for water infused with chunks of freshly cut fruit such as berries. Worryingly 23 per cent of the population choose fizzy drinks to stay hydrated. While two thirds never check the calorie count in what they are drinking - in fact, only a fifth check the ingredients of drinks before consuming them.  Almost half believe no added sugar squash is better for you than regular squash. Dr Emma Derbyshire added: “People across the country are becoming more conscious about what they are eating. “However, many are still overlook what they are drinking - and in some instances energy and sugars can tally up. “There are many healthy and delicious ways to beat dehydration. For example, try adding mixed berries to your water. “Adding three to four mixed berries - raspberries, blueberries and strawberries - could help increase your vitamin C consumption. “So, not only does it keep you hydrated, taste great, it also has added health benefits.”

story: NewsInside 'annex of horror' left full of needles and rotting food by tenant - but landlord must pay for clean upThe tenant, aged in his 50s, has lived in the den of squalor for five years - but the council says it is the landlords' responsibility to clean it upShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAlex Richards reporter19:59, 13 AUG 2018NewsPictures show the filthy condition the family found the property in (Image: Devon Live WS)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn annex littered with used needles, urine and rotting food has been deemed so vile even workmen are refusing to go inside. Stomach churning photographs show the extent of the disrepair of the property in Exmouth piled with rubbish and cigarette butts. Now the family who recently inherited the property from the late landlord have hit out at the council for its lack of help.  The family were gobsmacked to discover conditions lived in by a tenant not paying his bills, reports Devon Live .  But, because they didn't go through legal channels to serve the man a written notice, East Devon District Council say he is allowed to remain.  Adding insult to injury, an order has been slapped on the family telling them to fork out and make it habitable before being able to formally re-let.
