title: louis vuitton model george koh
story: NewsLouis Vuitton model George Koh fatally knifes rival in horror CCTV footage before later wiping blade on jeansGeorge Koh, 24, was convicted of murdering Harry Uzoka, who was stabbed in the heart in the brutal attack in West LondonShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByDave Burke18:12, 13 AUG 2018Updated20:11, 13 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailChilling CCTV footage shows a jealous Louis Vuitton model chasing a rival accompanied by two friends before later wiping blood from his jeans after a brutal murder.  George Koh, 24, was today convicted of murdering Harry Uzoka .  The two had fallen out after Koh claimed to have slept with the victim's girlfriend, and Mr Uzoka accused him of being fake. The rivals had arranged to settle the row 'face to face' in Shepherds Bush, West London, on January 11 this year. Mr Uzoka, 25, recruited his flatmate, Adrian Harper, as back-up and the pair arrived armed with a dumbbell bar each.  But Koh was waiting with a knife in each hand accompanied by 'big, burly, strong' pals Merse Dikanda, wielding a 'terrifying' machete, and personal trainer Jonathan Okigbo, both also 24. When the rivals confronted each other, Harry and his friend revealed the dumbbell bars before Koh - seen in the footage wearing a green parka - stated are you mad? and pulled out two knives. Okigbo, wearing a blue jacket, reached over to a black bag held by Dikanda - wearing a black jacket and hood - and pulled out an object with a black handle, stating I want to let this off at you.  Moments later Dikanda pulled out a machete. Harry’s friend fled immediately on sight of the weapons, followed by Harry, who was pursued by Koh and Dikanda, both armed with a machete and knives, and trapped Harry against a vehicle. Okigbo chased after Harry’s flatmate to ensure he would not return.  Harry, who was surrounded by the three men, was stabbed by Koh, three times, with one of the wounds penetrating his chest. He was able to escape, but moments later collapsed in the street as the men walked off in the opposite direction. Police and paramedics were called shortly before 4pm by a member of the public who found Harry collapsed and bleeding in the street. He died shortly over an hour later. After the brutal attack the trio had hid in a doorway, close to the crime, unaware that CCTV had recorded Koh wiping a blade on his jeans. Okigbo meanwhile had removed a distinctive jacket he was wearing.

title: mum who kept waking up
story: NewsMum who kept waking up to odd "herbal" smell in dead of night told she has 18 months to liveEXCLUSIVE: Mel Mirza, 44, was horrified to discover she had a golf ball-sized tumour inside her brain that would claim her life within 12 to 18 monthsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByChris kitching14:07, 13 AUG 2018Updated17:33, 13 AUG 2018NewsMel Mirza, pictured with six-year-old son Casey, was horrified to discover she had 12 to 18 months to live (Image: Mirror Pix)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen Mel Mirza started suffering from agonising 24-hour headaches and waking up to an odd herbal smell in the dead of night, she knew something was seriously wrong. So when doctors told her she was likely stressed or depressed, the married mum-of-four refused to listen - instead pressing for more tests to find out the cause of her worrying symptoms. Eventually, she discovered the horrifying truth - she had a cancerous tumour the size of a golf ball in her brain that would claim her life within 12 to 18 months. I was experiencing severe, painful headaches that were 24 hours a day, Mel, from Harlow, Essex, told .  I used to wake up at 4am with these bizarre smells. It's a smell I have never smelt before. It was like a herbal smell that was very unusual. And I had these attacks that got worse and worse. I would have to sit down to get out of them. An oncologist eventually said the attacks were a form of a seizure. I was worried it was an aneurysm. She added that finding out she had a brain tumour was devastating. My mum just fell apart and my sister grabbed hold of me, she said. Since her diagnosis last summer, the 44-year-old mum has put up a stoic fight to prolong her life and has remained upbeat despite an uncertain future.  But she has suffered a heartbreaking setback - a new tumour is growing in a different part of her brain and she will have to pay privately for the treatment she needs. She doesn't feel she is getting enough answers from medics in the UK, and is frustrated by limited treatment options available on the NHS and the high cost of alternative therapies in the UK and abroad. She said: I was told that the original tumour was shrinking and the cavity was shrinking. Then I had my most recent MRI in June after I had two seizures close together, and there’s a new area of disease developing in a different part of my brain. I’m strong and I’m positive, and I want to beat this. Unfortunately I don’t have hundreds of thousands of pounds to get the treatment I need. For them to say there’s a recurrence already while I am on chemotherapy is worrying. Brain tumours are notoriously difficult to diagnose, as there are more than 120 different types, says Brain Tumour Research. Most develop from glial cells that support the nerve cells of the brain. And they can present themselves with a wide variety of symptoms, depending on which part of the brain is affected. The most common symptoms - usually headaches and/or vomiting/nausea - occur when the growing tumour increases pressure in the skull. The headaches can be severe and persistent, and are often worse in the morning. Other symptoms of intracranial pressure can include:  Visual disturbance Convulsions (fits or faints, particularly for those over 40) Confusion  Other common symptoms can include:   Loss of balance or co-ordination Numbness or weakness on one side of the body Changes in personality Impaired memory or mental ability such as loss of intellect, blurred or double vision, changes in senses including small and hearing, problems with speech, writing or drawing, and problems with averting the eyes upwards  Brain stem symptoms can include lack of co-ordination when walking, double vision, difficulty in swallowing and speaking, and facial weakness such as a one-sided smile or drooping eyelid. Brain Tumour Research says: In order to diagnose the presence of a brain tumour an MRI or CT scan is imperative. If your doctor has failed to satisfy you as to the cause of your symptoms be adamant about getting a referral to a specialist, who should then send you for such a scan. Mel and her family are now trying to raise &pound200,000 to pay for pioneering treatment at a wonder clinic in Germany. She was diagnosed with the aggressive glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) tumour in June last year after she began feeling unwell. The mum, who has been positive and open about her condition, had started noticing her symptoms in January and soon went to the GP. She said: I kept coming down with illness and I was worried because I was getting heart palpitations and just being sick all the time, with colds. I went to the GP and they said I had a sinus infection and gave me antibiotics, and then I was told I had a chest infection. In March last year it just got worse. She described how she began noticing strange smells, having seizures and experiencing unbearable headaches - that grew more severe. She went to the GP again and was put through a battery of tests, including blood analysis and an ultrasound of her stomach.  For her family, the fact that Mel, who worked as a carer at a retirement home, sought help was a sign that something was very wrong with her. Her sister Nikki Lee, 43, said: Mel isn't the type to go to the doctor or to the hospital. The fact that she went to the doctor, we knew it had to be something she felt wasn't right. Despite all the tests, none revealed the tumour inside Mel's head. The mum said: A nurse told me you have had a lot of tests and nothing is coming up, so it's probably stress. I told her I am not a high-stress person. I never get stressed, and I wasn't stressed. I am used to multi-tasking - working 48 hours a week and raising four children - and I am a coper. She added: Another doctor told me it was depression and I said 'no'. They put me on antidepressants that would help with the pain of my headaches.  Neither Mel nor her family were satisfied with those diagnoses, so they kept pressing for answers. Mel said: In the end, my mum said 'No, I've had enough of this'. Her aunt had an aneurysm and she wanted me to be referred to a specialist. She added that her mum wanted her to have a full-body scan. Last June, she went for a CT scan and left not knowing what the results would show or when she would find out. But about 90 minutes later, her doctor rang her and told her to come to his surgery - along with her mother Pauline, 72 - within the hour. Mel said: I thought, 'Oh dear, this can't be good'. We went, and he told us the devastating news that I had a brain tumour the size of a golf ball. She added: I took it well, really.  I asked what's next and the GP said he would try to get me into a specialist hospital to remove it, but to go to a local hospital if I get worse. The next day I was constantly being sick, so my sister and my mum took me up to the A&ampE. They gave me a full-body scan to see if the cancer was anywhere else in my body, but they said it wasn't. Three days later, Mel was transferred to a different hospital where she underwent surgery to remove as much of the tumour as possible. Surgeons had removed about 85 per cent of it, but there was more bad news the following week when she was given the results. Mel said: My oncology nurse told me, unfortunately, that it was the worst news. It was the worst form [of tumour]. I wanted to hear how we will beat it. They told me I would get six weeks of radiotherapy and then chemotherapy, but there was nothing else to offer. Brain tumours are indiscriminate and can affect anyone at any age, but they kill more children and adults under 40 than any other cancer. Yet just one per cent of the national spend on cancer research has been allocated to brain tumours, according to campaigners.  In the UK, about 16,000 people are diagnosed each year with a brain tumour - or almost 44 people a day. It is estimated that more than 5,000 people lose their lives to a brain tumour die each year. Less than 20 per cent of those diagnosed with a brain tumour survive beyond five years compared with an average of 50 per cent across all cancers. Brain tumours kill more children than leukaemia, more women under 35 than breast cancer and more men under 45 than prostate cancer, according to Brain Tumour Research.  She added: They removed 85 per cent of the tumour, but what’s very frustrating is even that's a very grey area. It’s all very vague, they're unable to say for sure how much is left in there. Mel and Nikki have been left frustrated, they say, because no-one can give them definite answers. Nikki said: You’re hit with this devastating diagnosis … you want to know what you can do to get better, but nobody can answer that. Mel has refused to let the diagnosis derail her life. Just four days after she was released from hospital after surgery, she went to an Ed Sheeran gig in Camden, north London. Nikki said: She was just going up to everybody and telling everyone, 'I just had brain surgery' and what her diagnosis was. You think, 'Be careful, you just had brain surgery', but Mel was behaving like she had just had some minor surgery.  Mel added: I was dancing and singing, and I had a great time. You have to get on with things, don't you? I said, 'I am going to go and enjoy myself'. The diagnosis was a devastating blow to Mel's family, and it has put her and her bus driver husband Simon, 53, under financial duress at the worst possible time. Mel can no longer work as a carer or drive a car due to the tumour, meaning the family are on a single income and Simon has had to work overtime to make ends meet while also caring for his wife. She said: My husband is amazing. He does overtime all the time. He's very loving and supporting. The couple's children - sons Dylan, 22, Reece, 20, and Casey, six, and daughter Paige, 16 - don't know how long their mum will be in their lives. Mel said: It has devastated the whole family. My kids have looked up the disease on the Internet, and they saw how bleak it is. My 16-year-old daughter, she said 'we all know, we've all looked it up'. She has been stressed and unwell. She also fears her condition is hereditary. She added: It’s something I really worry about all the time. My daughter suffers from migraines.  Mel has suffered from chronic seizures since she underwent surgery to remove the tumour, and can hear an alarm ringing in her ears when one is about to strike. She said: I will say, 'Can you hear that noise?' to the kids and they will tell me no. It feels like when your ears have popped and it sounds really low. So then I know it is coming and I lower myself to the floor. The first time I heard the alarm I didn't know what was going to happen. I started shaking and my daughter called my husband, and he got me on my side and held me. My body is giving me a warning. Some people detect a burning smell. Mel is still undergoing chemotherapy after another round of radiotherapy, and is paying for treatments at Care Oncology Clinic in Marylebone, central London thanks to the financial support of loved ones. She is focused on leading a healthy lifestyle, hoping it will give her more time. She exercises as much as she can and is following a strict diet of foods that are said to help cancer patients. Related video: Cancer mum given months to live helped by Kate Winslet Medical experts still don't know what causes brain tumours, as the number of cases and deaths rise by the thousands in Britain every year. Less than 20 per cent survive beyond five years of being diagnosed, and they can affect anyone at any age. Brain tumours kill more children and adults under the age of 40 than any other cancer, and they kill more children than leukaemia. But just one per cent of the national spend on cancer research has been allocated to brain tumours, says the charity Brain Tumour Research. It has challenged the government and larger cancer charities to invest more money in research. Dr Kieran Breen, Director of Research at Brain Tumour Research, said: “Bethany’s tumour type, ganglioglioma, tend to be relatively slow-growing, however there is very little conclusive research indicating what causes brain tumours. They can affect anyone at any age, while treatments remain limited, with only two commonly-prescribed chemotherapy drugs available. More research into brain tumours is desperately needed to improve outcomes for patients as the current situation is shocking. Dr Breen added: “Brain tumours kill more children and adults under the age of 40 than any other cancer. There are 16,000 new cases diagnosed in the UK each year, and incidence is rising. The lack of research investment into this form of cancer means that survival rates lag behind other cancers. For example, around 80 per cent of people with breast cancer survive up to five years after treatment. In brain tumours it’s just 20 per cent.”

title: railways went wrong how fix
story: NewsWhere the railways went wrong - and how to fix it after months of delay woesChristian Wolmar gives his view on how we get the railways back on track after months and months of delay woesShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByChristian Wolmar22:32, 13 AUG 2018Updated22:40, 13 AUG 2018NewsChristian Wolmar has given his view on how to get the railways back on track (Image: Hulton Archive)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBarely a day goes by without another nightmare rail tale. For the third Sunday running, Northern Rail cancelled dozens of scheduled services as new timetable disruptions persist. That’s the “new” timetable introduced back in May. Fares increases are about to be announced, while customer satisfaction goes the other way. Research has found the rail companies are the least trusted of 13 consumer industries except car dealers, due to problems with train punctuality and reliability. How did an industry once so admired hit the buffers so hard?  For once Margaret Thatcher is not to blame. One of the few good things the ex-PM ever did was NOT privatising the railways. It was, she realised, a bad idea as rail would always need plenty of government subsidy – and was a beloved part of Britain’s heritage. British Rail had got rid of its old-fashioned image by replacing steam trains with sleek InterCity diesel and electric ones that ran at 125mph and were the focus of one of the 1980s’ best ad campaigns: “Let the train take the strain.” Her successor John Major, though, was too weak to stop his right-wingers pushing through plans to sell off the railways. So the idea became a key part of his 1992 manifesto for an election he was not expected to win. When the Tories did in fact retain power he let the ideologues create the most damaging model of privatisation. Major liked the romantic idea of recreating the big four rail companies, based around regions such as Great Western and Southern, which existed from 1923 until nationalisation in 1948.  It was a sensible notion, as it would have created proper rail firms. Instead, he was again pushed by his more ideological ministers into creating a model that involved breaking up the railways into more than 100 organisations and selling as many as possible. Wide expertise was lost in this scorched earth policy. Track and infrastructure were hived off as a separate company, Railtrack. This was subsequently flogged off but went bust and had to be rescued by the Government. Operations were split between 25 firms, many of which also went bust and had to be saved by the state. The engineering department was split into 13 companies. Again several collapsed – most recently Carillion, which had to be rescued by Network Rail. BR’s well-regarded research unit was disbanded and its coachworks mostly closed. We have ever since suffered from the consequences of that disastrous decision, which lies at the root of today’s troubles. Take the recent chaos on timetables. NR draws these up on the basis of demands by the train operators, which have contracts with government to run particular services. However, no one bothered to check if there was enough space on the tracks to accommodate all the extra trains that the operators wanted to run. Moreover, NR produced draft timetable plans late, so operators had no time to prepare for new schedules by, for example, training enough drivers. This was partly because NR’s regulator, the Office of Rail and Road, put the firm under pressure to cut back on the number of timetable staff, which the ORR felt were an unnecessary luxury. To worsen matters, NR failed to deliver some of the track improvements, particularly electrification, needed for the extra trains. This had a knock-on effect, as some of the old diesels used on these lines had been earmarked for other parts of the network. Moreover, in the rush to implement plans, drivers’ rosters were changed arbitrarily, with the result that they were in no mood to volunteer for Sunday shifts. At this point, enter Transport Secretary Chris Grayling. With so many organisations involved, he is the only person with power to ensure co-ordination between them. After all, the Government has a huge say on railways as it owns NR and determines franchise terms. So Grayling could have stopped the massive timetable changes of May 20 – but he did not. Later he said: “I do not run the railways.” Yet he makes many of the decisions that affect them and wants to take credit for improvements. He does not, however, want to take responsibility for things that have gone wrong.

title: friend who pushed teen 60ft
story: NewsFriend who pushed teen off 60ft bridge leaving her with horrific injuries 'pictured partying days later'The social media posts have angered the family of Jordan Holgerson, who "can hardly walk" after plunging into a riverShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByChris kitching13:33, 13 AUG 2018Updated13:55, 13 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman who pushed a teenager off a bridge has angered the girl's family by partying with pals after the horror fall, it was claimed. Jordan Holgerson suffered five broken ribs, a lung injury and several abrasions, and can hardly walk after plunging into a river. Footage showed the 16-year-old standing nervously at the edge of the bridge and twice telling her friends 'no' before one pushed her from behind. That friend has since been going out as if nothing happened while Jordan faces a long recovery, a source close to the Holgerson family claims.   The friend who allegedly pushed Jordan - identified by the Sun as 18-year-old Taylor Smith - posed with a friend at the Clark County Fair in a post on Instagram on Saturday, the newspaper reported.  Jordan's family have been left angered by the social media posts and claim Taylor hasn't been to visit her since the incident last Tuesday. A family source told the Sun: “Taylor has been going out as if nothing happened.  “She's been at a pool party and there were pictures of her at the county fair with a friend on Instagram. “Jordan can hardly walk and is in so much pain - she can't do any of those things. The source added: “She clearly doesn't care.  The source also claimed that Taylor hasn't visited Jordan to see if she is OK, and sent a message to say she was sorry.   Jordan's mum told the Thoroughbred Daily News that the teen is lucky not be paralysed or dead.  Police have not released the names of those involved when Jordan fell 60ft from Moulton Falls and landed in the Lewis River in Yacolt, Washington, in the US.  Officers are still investigating the incident. The video shows Jordan kicking her arms and flailing her arms helplessly in a panic as she falls to the water below. Ashley Mahree, who recorded the video and posted it online, wrote in a YouTube description: “This could have easily taken a life, and I think this girl needs to be held accountable in some way.  She added: The person that pushed her should go to jail. Jordan, who said she blacked out as she fell towards the river, was in a neck brace in hospital following the incident. Someone swam out and rescued her before she was rushed to hospital.

title: terrifying moment man tries snatch
story: NewsTerrifying moment man tries to snatch girl walking with her mum by yanking backpack and refusing to let goThe would-be kidnapper, who worked as a lifeguard at a local swimming pool, was stopped by passersbyShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByKelly-Ann Mills12:34, 13 AUG 2018Updated12:43, 13 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThis is the terrifying moment a man grabs a little girl out walking with her mum and refuses to let go. He lunged towards the seven-year-old and yanked her backpack so hard she was lifted off her feet. The youngster's panicking mother held on to her daughter's arms in a desperate bid to save her child.  CCTV images from the Neihu district in Taiwanese capital Taipei shows the mum, named in local reports as  Mrs Wu, walking the child home from school when the man strikes.  The suspect, 33-year-old Chou, who worked as a lifeguard at a local swimming pool, later claimed it was a case of 'mistaken identity'.  He has now been arrested on kidnapping charges. In the disturbing footage the girl appears to scream and her mother does too, with the parent desperately trying to pull her daughter away. The girl is lifted into the air and the two grown-ups become involved in a game of human tug-of-war. Restaurant staff and a number of passers-by came to the mother's aid and Chou eventually let go and walked away from the area. Mrs Wu and her daughter were both shaken by the incident but not injured, police from Dahu Precinct said.

title: woman buys coffee lady behind
story: NewsWoman buys coffee for lady behind her at Starbucks - then finds sweet surprise in her mailbox laterA woman named Mackenzie has revealed how a kind gesture she made for a stranger has resulted in a sweet new friendshipShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer12:55, 13 AUG 2018Updated14:10, 13 AUG 2018NewsA woman's act of kindness in Starbucks has gone viral (stock photo) (Image: REUTERS)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailYou never know exactly what is going on in someone else's life.  Everyone has their own secrets and struggles and sometimes a small, random, act of kindness can mean the world to another human being.  Whether it's opening a door for someone else, offering some a little bit of spare change or just flashing someone a smile, it can make a big difference.  This is the lesson one woman from Ohio, USA learned after she did something nice for a stranger in Starbucks .   The woman, called Mackenzie, purchased a coffee for the lady behind her in the queue at the popular hot drinks chain. She just thought she was merely doing a sweet thing, but little did she know, she'd made a lasting impact.  Mackenzie revealed all in a Twitter post , which has since gone viral, with 20,000 shares and 80,000 likes.  She said: Yesterday I bought coffee for the lady behind me at Starbucks. Later in the day I found this is my mailbox. Small acts can make a big difference folks, spread some kindness.  The item she found in her mailbox was a thank you letter from the woman she'd bought the drink for, whose name was Nicole. Nicole revealed how she very rarely treats herself to things like Starbucks, but she had been going through a bit of a hard time and was hoping to cheer herself up with a nice drink. Thank you for the coffee! I rarely go to Starbucks and treat myself, but the last couple of months have been a bit of a struggle, she wrote. My father just passed away and he was also my babysitter. My family and my children have had a really hard time.  This morning my babysitter called off sick and I had to take the day off work. I decided to buy my kids breakfast and get myself a coffee with total guilt because I am going to be a stay-at-home-mom for a while. She added that she was not emotionally or financially prepared for this sudden life change and that she cried when she found out what Mackenzie had done for her. But the story gets more interesting. As Nicole headed home, she recognised one of her neighbours as the kind girl from the coffee shop.  It turns out the pair live just down the street from one another, so Nicole decided to take the opportunity to explain just how much the beverage had meant to her. I felt it necessary for you to know that what you did for me was more than just a coffee. It was something that has turned my whole day around, put tears in my eyes and a smile on my face, continued Nicole. She finished the letter by saying she was so grateful. Lots of people loved the tweet, with many commenting that they thought it was so sweet and thoughtful.

title: yemen could turn syria plus
story: NewsYemen could turn into 'Syria plus' after Saudi airstrike kills more than 40 childrenWARNING - GRAPHIC CONTENT: The United Nations says victims aged between 10 and 13 whose bus was hit by an airstrike were killed by a Saudi Arabia-led coalitionShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByChris HughesDefence and Security Editor22:50, 10 AUG 2018Updated22:51, 10 AUG 2018NewsAn airstrike in Yemen has left 40 youngsters dead and many more injured (Image: AFP)Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The deaths of over 40 children in Yemen in a suspected Saudi airstrike is the latest sign it could turn into “Syria plus” if the bloodshed is not stopped, the UN warned yesterday.   British UN envoy Mark Griffith, speaking in the wake of dozens of civilians being killed in a bus blast, warned of “massive humanitarian suffering” if the bloodshed continues.  He said: “A failed state in Yemen has extraordinary consequences for the region, and the wider region, and beyond. And it’s not that inconceivable that could happen. We have to act now. “We also need to act now because in my judgment the war in Yemen will get more complicated the longer it goes on. “There will be more international interest and polarisation in terms of the parties, it will fragment further, it will be more difficult to resolve - even than it is now.”  He added: “My worry about Yemen is that if we left it and it wasn’t resolved, we could look at Syria-plus in the years to come.” The bodies of about 40 children were among scores killed in an airstrike in Saada province, the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) said. The UK Government faces calls to cease selling arms and providing military advice to Saudi Arabia, which leads a coalition that carried out the strike. Iran is supporting Houthi rebels who are being hammered from the air by the Saudi-led coalition in one of the Middle East’s most brutal proxy wars in decades. According to the UN the youngsters had been at a summer camp when the bus was struck on Thursday, with most of the dead between 10 and 13 years old.

title: csaba achieves one of our remaining aims by bringing target man to dundee united
story: Dundee United have secured the signing of Slovak striker Pavol Šafranko on a season-long loan from Danish Superleague side Aalborg BK.The 6-ft 1-inch, 23-year-old played under Csaba Laszlo at DAC Dunajska Streda before moving to ABK in August 2017.Pavol has played twice for the Slovak national team and scored three goals in eight appearances for the Under 21s, and lists Tatran Prešov and Železiarne Podbrezová as previous clubs.Manager Csaba Laszlo said: &#8220It was one of our remaining aims to acquire a target man, and Pavol fits that role.&#8220I know him from our time together at DAC and believe we are getting a striker who will complement the players already here. I feel pleased to have secured his services for the season.&#8221Pavol said: &#8220The opportunity to come and play in Scotland for a club like Dundee United, as well as to be reunited with Csaba Laszlo excited me. I want to help this club reach the top league this season.&#8220I now look forward to meeting my new teammates and putting on the famous tangerine jersey.&#8221

title: dundee boss mccann says nothing is happening with lawrence as jones set to sign instead
story: Neil McCann insists there is “nothing happening” in relation to a deal bringing Lawrence Shankland to Dens Park.Instead, the Dundee gaffer is set to add Shrewsbury striker Sam Jones to his attack.Speaking yesterday, Neil said: “Sam Jones is one we have looked at, one of a few but I don’t want to be disrespectful to Shrewsbury by commenting too much on it.“We have looked at him. We have asked the question and spoken to the club and I believe there is an agreement there but there is nothing agreed with him yet.”Ayr striker Shankland, who has started the season in scintillating form with nine goals in five games, has been linked with a move to Dundee in recent weeks.It was reported on Thursday that the newly-promoted Championship club had rejected a bid from an English side for their striker, but McCann, who has made it clear he is keen to add to his attacking options, played down his interest.“It’s really unfair to comment on any players I am after,” he said. “What I would say is that I have been in the market and been actively trying to get players.“Some have come close and fallen through, others not.“Lawrence is a very talented player.“I know him from my time at Dunfermline and have no doubt he could come to a club like Dundee and do very well, especially in the Premiership.“But as it stands there is nothing happening.”He added: “We tried to do some business on Thursday, it didn’t quite happen but we will continue working on that.”Dundee &#8216agree deal&#8217 for English attacker

title: dundee boss neil mccann delight at deacon return saying he could be massive
story: Dundee boss Neil McCann is delighted to see “a player who could be really massive for us this year” has returned to training.Winger Roarie Deacon is yet to feature for the Dark Blues at all since the final day of last season after picking up an ankle injury in the 1-0 defeat to Partick Thistle.At the time, the injury didn’t seem too serious but eventually required surgery and has kept Deacon out of action for the entirety of pre-season and the beginning of the campaign.Last week, though, he posted photos on social media of his return to training and his boss was delighted to see the former Arsenal kid back in action.Neil said: “I was really delighted to see him back.“I was sick for Deacon because he got himself into great shape last year and he was so looking forward to hitting the ground running in pre- season but then he picked up a really innocuous injury against Partick.“He’s back running and I’m delighted with that because he’s a player that could be really massive for us this year.”Deacon remains a few weeks away from a return.When he does become available once more for selection, Neil admits he’ll have welcome decisions to make between his players.Something central midfielder Lewis Spence has given him thanks to his form of late.“We want to have decisions to make all over the place,” Neil added.“I thought Lewis’ display was brilliant last week. Maybe he just reinforced why I brought him to the club. Last year he was unfortunate with injury but I’m hoping he’s just one of many who tries to force his way into my starting XI.“If I get enough of those guys pushing then I’ve got a good headache to have this season.”

title: dundee boss neil mccann on leeds united target steven caulker i thought we would lose him
story: Neil McCann was left relieved after managing to hold on to a couple of key players as the English transfer window shut on Thursday afternoon.Glen Kamara and Steven Caulker were both linked with a move down south &#8211 with Leeds rumoured to be interested in the latter &#8211 but remain with Dundee, and McCann says there were never any offers despite the reported interest.“There have been no official bids put on the table yet for Steven,” he said. “Clearly he is a player that attracts a lot of interest.“The good thing is, I thought he would probably go and we would lose him, but we still have him.“We need to be thankful for the squad we have just now, because we could have lost a few players to down south.”

title: dundee sweat over fitness of star midfielder glen kamara for aberdeen clash
story: Dundee are sweating over the fitness of star midfielder Glen Kamara ahead of today’s visit of Aberdeen.The Finnish international went over his ankle three weeks ago and missed the Betfred Cup games against Peterhead and Brechin.He was expected to be fit for the Premiership opener at St Mirren last weekend but suffered a reaction to the injury on the eve of the game in Paisley.It’s unclear yet just how long that will keep the central midfielder out for but he is a big doubt for today’s home clash with the Dons.Despite falling to a 2-1 defeat to the Buddies, the Dark Blues midfield didn’t miss Kamara’s presence too much with Lewis Spence an able deputy with Kharl Madianga, Elton Ngwatala and Paul McGowan ahead of him also performing well.And those four are expected to continue today from the start.Meanwhile, the English transfer window shutting yesterday evening was good news for Dundee fans with Kamara and Steven Caulker still at the club.Kamara had been linked with a move to newly- promoted Premier League side Wolves and Championship Swansea.Loan moves are still available to Football League clubs but the Dark Blues would be unlikely to accept a loan-to-buy deal with the 22-year-old’s contract expiring at the end of the season.Both Celtic and Rangers had been credited with interest in the midfielder and they have till the end of the month to make a move if they so wish.Central defender Caulker had been linked with a £1.5 million move to Leeds United this week but that failed to materialise.Turkish side Trabzonspor have also been credited with interest in the England international.

title: dundee united boss csaba laszlo mulls changes as he seeks better show at queens
story: Dundee United boss Csaba Laszlo faces some key selection decisions as he tries to get his team back to winning ways at Queen of the South today.After an opening day league defeat that saw three goals conceded in the second half against Dunfermline last week, his desire to make changes is obvious.However, a number of factors, not least fitness, will come into play before he finalises his line-up.Stewart Murdoch could return to the defence if he’s recovered from the swollen knee that forced him to sit out the Pars clash and the recent Betfred Cup trip to Elgin.And if he’s come through training this week without any reaction to the knock that’s sidelined him since last month’s defeat at Ross County, full-back Callum Booth will also return to the squad.After almost a month out, though, it may be the best he can hope for is a place on the bench.And the fact today sees United’s first outing of the campaign on a synthetic surface could be a factor in whether or not the pair are involved.Whoever he decides, or is able to use, Csaba will be looking for much better this time round.While injuries have ruled out various key players in the games so far, he believes those taking their places should be doing so with the aim of hanging on to them even if everyone is fit.“I have said to the team you cannot wait for Fraser Fyvie or Stewart Murdoch or Callum Booth or Billy King,” he said.“You should not just be a shadow for these players, you have to deliver, make competition for places.“They want to play in the first XI when they are fit – do you want to just give them your place?”

title: neil mccann says dundee need help of new striker but reveals budget worry
story: Neil McCann fears he may be priced out of finding the striker he needs to sort Dundee&#8217s shot-shy attack.The Dens Park boss is worried his budget might not stretch far enough to bring in the quality frontman he requires after seeing his side lose 1-0 to Aberdeen.For the second week running the Dark Blues had chances to go in front.But like in their opening-day loss at St Mirren, defeat was self-inflicted as Genseric Kusunga&#8217s handball in the box handed Gary Mackay-Steven the chance to tuck home the only goal from the spot with quarter of an hour left.McCann&#8217s men are sitting with nothing to show for their efforts and the Dundee chief knows he needs to bring in new competition for frontmen Sofien Moussa and Jean Mendy after both wasted golden opportunities against the Dons.&#8220We need help in that department, we need someone in for that area,&#8221 he said.&#8220There is no update on anyone, it&#8217s difficult in the market with the budget we work on.&#8220The problem is the money down in England, it&#8217s very competitive and we are priced out of so many markets.&#8220You just have to be patient and hope one comes up that fits the budget.&#8221Former Dundee United winger Mackay-Steven took flak as he made his return to Tayside but the 27-year-old had the last laugh as he stroked home the winner late on.&#8220I always seem to get a bit of stick here but I was delighted to get the win,&#8221 he said after Aberdeen grabbed all three points, having missed their own fair share of chances.&#8220I was happy to stroke the penalty away in the end. I was confident again &#8211 it was my penalty.&#8220The way we won shows a lot about us. Dundee are a good side and certain things didn&#8217t go our way. But we just wanted to keep plugging away and getting down the sides, for myself and Niall McGinn to keep getting at our full-backs and getting balls into the box.&#8220We&#8217ve got quality all over the pitch so we knew we&#8217d create chances &#8211 it was just a case of taking one.&#8221

title: rejected sam jones turns down dundee after talks with neil mccann
story: Dundee manager Neil McCann has been hit with a blow in his bid to sign a goalscorer after he was turned down by Sam Jones.Dundee and Shrewsbury Town had agreed a five-figure fee and the 26-year-old saw was a Dens Park spectator in the directors&#8217 box on Saturday as McCann&#8217s men went down 1-0 to Aberdeen.But after considering a switch to the SPFL, he has now returned to the Shrews and trained with John Askey’s squad today.Although born in Barnsley, he has represented Wales youth at youth level.Jones only joined the Shrews in January after spells at National League outfit Gateshead and League Two Grimsby Town that saw him among the goals on a regular basis.

title: Ben Nevis climb in aid of toddler Leo
story: &nbspPARENTS of a brave Inverness three-year-old will be joined by a fundraising army of friends and family as they climb Ben Nevis on tomorrow.Around 70 people will climb Scotland' tallest peak to raise funds for Leo Flett, a toddler with a rare genetic condition.The youngster, from Balloch, suffers from congenital muscular dystrophy which has left him needing to be fed through a tube and has prevented him from learning to walk.The fundraising campaign is called Leo' Pride. The group tackling Ben Nevis will be led by Leo' parents, Louise and Mitchell Flett, while another group from Results Fitness in Inverness will be led by personal trainer Kevin Campbell as they take on the Three Peaks Challenge.The smaller group will attempt to conquer the three highest mountains in Scotland, Wales and England in just 24 hours.Mrs Flett wanted to thank them for signing up to the "incredible" challenge."Leo is our whole world and he deserves the best chance possible," she said."We want to thank each and every person who has registered to take part in the event &ndash it is so special for us."Everyone I have spoken to is so excited about the weekend."She said there would be a huge mix of ages and people taking part, with close friends, pals from school and people she has never met before, all travelling to take on the challenge.As so few people have Muscular Dystrophy type 1C like Leo, very little is known about it. Cash raised during the challenge will help to fund research into the condition and provide equipment for Leo as he gets older.He has been in and out of hospital repeatedly throughout his short life and without medical physio, delivered by his parents and specialist doctors, could well have succumbed to complications caused by a common cold or flu.As Leo grows the extra weight will put pressure on his body and there is a possibility of him developing further complications.He currently attends Duncan Forbes Nursery and his parents describe him as "a lovely little boy" with a love for Paw Patrol cartoons.Leo will be waiting at the bottom of Ben Nevis with his grandparents and brother and his parents says it will be "all the motivation" they need to complete the climb.To donate to the appeal visit www.justgiving/fundraising/louise-flett2Tuesday 14 Aug 2018 4:36 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Cash raised in memory of tragic tot
story: &nbspA BANNER in memory of a toddler who died in his sleep is to hang in Caley Thistle' stadium in tribute to him.James Anderson was just 16 months old when he was a victim of cot death last October, but in his short life he attended many football games with his family.Since autumn his grieving family have been working with the Angel Wings Baby and Child Loss charity to create the Baby James Legacy.And thanks to the help of local fundraisers, they have collected thousands of pounds for snuggle blankets and cuddle cots to let grieving Highland families spend a little extra time saying goodbye to their loved ones.James&rsquo maternal grandmother, Liz MacRae, of Nethybridge, was delighted to receive the support of Inverness Caledonian Thistle Football Club, which has made the charity its "cause of the year"."I have been a season holder and supporter for years and James was a season holder too," she said."As soon as he passed away the chairman contacted us to pass on his condolences."The club wanted to do something to help and will be running fundraising raffles and allowing the family to hold bucket collections at games."You don&rsquot want people to forget about him, the piercing blue eyes, the mad curly hair and how he was always such a smiley baby," Ms MacRae said.She designed the banner herself with the football club to represent herself and James&rsquo mum Jessica Anderson.It also has a shinty emblem, to represent James&rsquo father Craig Macleod.Ms MacRae said she wanted to raise awareness of the charity so more families knew about the help available to them when they lose a child.To donate, visit www.gofundme/jamess-snuggle-matTuesday 14 Aug 2018 4:36 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Casting vote gives approval for 115 new homes in Nairn
story: &nbspA CASTING vote decided a major housing development for Nairn, giving the go-ahead for 115 new homes despite a long list of residents&rsquo concerns.Objectors to the proposal for Kingsteps, Lochloy, on the east side of the town, cited "over-development", a lack of infrastructure, flood-risk, poor access, gridlock, loss of amenity and the presence of badgers as reasons to reject the plan.After a two-hour site visit by councillors, also attended by more than 50 local objectors, planning committee members returned to Inverness to discuss the application &ndash and voted 5-5.South planning committee chairman Jimmy Gray' casting vote swung the decision in Springfield Properties&rsquo favour, granting permission to transform fields beside Lochloy Road, owned by Nairn councillor Liz MacDonald. She did not participate in the process.Her successor as Nairn Provost, Laurie Fraser, forced a vote in the council chamber after arguing that the proposal would breach the Inner Moray Firth Local Development Plan on two counts &ndash by exacerbating traffic delays without provision of sufficient roads infrastructure, and by failing to guarantee a sufficient buffer zone between existing homes and the planned development.He appealed for a halt to further housing in the area until the promised A96 bypass is built.His ward colleague Tom Heggie, a fellow independent councillor, warned of the town becoming a "static community" if it was not allowed to grow.Conservative group leader Andrew Jarvie questioned the basis of traffic projections based on computer modelling, claiming they will underestimate the level of vehicle movements.Roads agency Transport Scotland did not agree with local concerns about access.Roddy Balfour, a member of the council' independent-led administration raised residents&rsquo fears about flood risk. He was told by principal planner Ken McCorquodale that the council' flood risk team was satisfied with the suitability of the site.Morton Gillespie of the Kingsteps Residents&rsquo Group said he was "extremely disappointed that Councillor Heggie did not back Councillor Fraser' motion, and "gave his own personal views rather than those of the people of Nairn".He added that he would be presenting photographic evidence of the presence of recent "active" badger setts within the development site. Mr McCorquodale had told the committee: "My understanding is there are no active setts."Springfield Properties chief executive Innes Smith said: "We&rsquore in a position to build 115 more new homes including 29 affordable homes in Nairn."This new development provides continuity of employment for over 50 people including apprentices, and supports 150 further jobs and local trades."Tuesday 14 Aug 2018 4:36 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Clash over retail plan for Cradlehall site
story: &nbspCOUNCILLORS have been directed to reject proposals for more shops in Cradlehall.Planning officials say a proposed development within the "neighbourhood centre" at Cradlehall Court and, in particular, the vehicle access to it would not blend in with the local environment.A strongly worded report emphasises that the purpose of the planning system is to "achieve the right development in the right place" and not at "any" cost.A briefing to the council' south planning committee says applicant Sean Kelly' vision would contravene the region' development plan.Cradlehall and Westhill Community Council supports the "in principal" planning application. The council' forestry officer opposes it on the basis of tree loss.The council' development plan team says "alternative retail and business sites exist elsewhere in the city".The report states there is "no proven need" for additional retail provision at the location, which adjoins an existing shopping centre.The applicant said land ownership issues prevented use of an existing access from Caulfield Road via Cradlehall Court to the 1.2-acre site.His alternative is a new access from Caulfield Road.A spokesman for Mr Kelly said: "The proposal is consistent with the local plan.The only available access has been agreed by the council' transport advisers. It' a proposal for important community facilities which is supported by the community council."Tuesday 14 Aug 2018 4:36 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Community council can no longer tolerate Eastgate Hostel inaction
story: &nbspFED-UP community leaders say they can no longer tolerate the lack of action over the fire-ravaged Eastgate Hostel building in Inverness city centre.Members of Crown and City Centre Community Council fear the wrangle over the building &ndash which went up in flames in 2013 &ndash will be a repeat of the impasse at the nearby B-listed Viewhill House which remains a prominent blot on the city' landscape since fire also struck there 11 years ago.They are calling on Highland Council either to approve redevelopment plans for the former hostel in Stephens Brae, or to acquire the eyesore building.Community council leader Pat Hayden said lessons had to be learned from the case of Viewhill House in Old Edinburgh Road.Once the home of renowned 19th century engineer Joseph Mitchell and later a youth hostel, it has remained derelict since the fire amid a legal wrangle between the present and former owners and a lack of funding for renovations."The former youth hostel at Viewhill is in our Crown area and is truly a blight on the landscape," Mrs Hayden said."We cannot allow Eastgate Hostel to follow suit, particularly as it is situated in such a prime city centre location."Members of the community council can no longer tolerate the lack of action regarding Eastgate Hostel."An application was lodged by the owners earlier this year to remove the scaffolding from the building and demolish the remaining structure ahead of construction.But it still has to be determined after a council officer and Historic Environment Scotland voiced disquiet about proposals to rebuild the facade at a lower height.In its submission to council planners, the community council states: "We urge the council to make every effort to resolve this situation, either by granting permission which might allow the applicants to proceed or alternatively, failing that, acquiring the building, presumably at a basic land value given its condition."James Maxwell, chairman of Inverness Civic Trust, said his organisation is also keen to see progress at the site,"Our basic position was that we wanted to see the whole of the frontage of the Eastgate building restored to the original design," he said."But if finances prevented that, as a compromise we did not object to salvaging part of it, provided architectural connectivity between the ground and first floor was preserved."Meanwhile chiropodist James Crawford, whose practice is close to the site, was contacted by Inverness city manager David Haas after his calls for a public meeting on the building' future were reported in the Inverness Courier.Mr Crawford has declined the offer of a private meeting with Mr Haas and the owners&rsquo agent."It has gone beyond that &ndash there should be a public meeting," he said."It is ridiculous that the unresolved issues at Eastgate and Viewhill have gone on for this long."Mr Haas said any interested parties could contact him and the main focus was currently to get the scaffolding down."There is great pressure on the owners to come up with a scheme to do that," he said.&nbsp&nbspA spokesman for the building' owners said: "We are working very closely with Highland Council to move this forward as quickly as possible. Circumstances are changing to allow us to move a lot quicker."Tuesday 14 Aug 2018 4:36 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Dozens apply for top job at council
story: &nbspTHERE has been a rush for the vacant &pound147,989 position of chief executive at Highland Council.A total of 28 people have applied for the job and a council source has hinted two of the applicants are council employees.Steve Barron will step down from the top job in the autumn after five years in the post.The council' press office refused to give any details about the process, saying recruitment matters were "confidential".A spokeswoman added: "On appointment of a new chief executive, the council will announce the appointment".The figure of 28 was, however, verified by Glasgow-based executive recruitment agency Aspen People.As part of the process, a cross-party panel of 25 councillors and trade union representatives will meet the job candidates on September 13 at Eden Court Theatre, after which a shortlist will be compiled.Each candidate will have 15 minutes to introduce themselves and answer questions at the theatre gathering.One councillor described it as "a sort of speed dating" event.Tuesday 14 Aug 2018 4:36 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Friends join 103 year old on her big day
story: &nbspTHE oldest woman in an Inverness care home celebrated her "big day" in style with a surprise party.Inverness-woman Muriel Lees turned 103 years old in Kingsmills Care Home on Monday.She was surrounded by her seven closest friends and care home staff for a special cake and rendition of the Happy Birthday song.Home manager, Carmen Delostrino and her staff decked out a room in the home with banners and balloons and would be hosting a lunch to celebrate."She likes her own space and getting her hair done every Thursday," she said."Muriel is a really nice lady and knows all of the staff by name, we have all been excited to surprise her because she appreciates everything so much and is just so lovely to everyone."She added: "She has been talking about her &lsquobig day&rsquo for a while and was looking forward to getting dressed up and spending it with her friends but she had no idea that she would be surprised by her other friends too."It feels like an achievement for us that she is so happy at 103 years old!"Tuesday 14 Aug 2018 4:36 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Merkinch beauty spot litter woes
story: &nbspTHE lack of consideration shown by people dumping their rubbish next to an Inverness beauty spot has been condemned by a community leader.Terry Ellison, chief executive of Merkinch Enterprise, voiced his frustration at those leaving their litter despite the provision of bins at the Merkinch Nature Reserve."The car park at the end of Kessock Road is always a wonderful place to park and relax with breathtaking views across the Beauly Firth, an abundance of wildlife to observe and the nature reserve to explore if you fancy stretching your legs," he said."I visit there most mornings before I start work and it never fails to dishearten and annoy me when there is more often than not rubbish strewn around the area."It is more frustrating when there are plenty of bins to use but there are people who simply cannot be bothered and who simply do not care."It is disrespectful and lazy."Mr Ellison acknowledged there were responsible people in the community who volunteered to carry out litter picks."To those groups and individuals, thank you," he said.Problem litter has been a big issue in a number of Highland communities in recent weeks and months &ndash sparking repeated pleas for more responsibility from the public.Just last week, High Life Highlands&rsquo countryside rangers appealed to walkers to take their rubbish home with them if they come across full bins, after piles of litter were left lying next to overflowing waste receptacles at popular beauty spots &ndash including the car park below Stac Pollaidh in Wester Ross.&nbspTheir comments echo the sentiments of Highland Council and the creators of the North Coast 500 in the spring, when they launched a "give your litter a lift" campaign urging people to take their rubbish home and not dump it in the countryside.Tuesday 14 Aug 2018 4:36 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Outlander landmark needs 100k investment
story: &nbspA HISTORIC landmark which is experiencing a dramatic rise in visitor numbers is in need of long overdue repairs and proper interpretation estimated to be about &pound100,000.Wardlaw Mausoleum in Kirkhill &ndash resting place of various Lovat Fraser family members &ndash is becoming a must-stop location for fans of the historical time travel Outlander book and TV series.The A-listed building has also in the spotlight in recent months after forensic experts carried out tests on remains contained in a coffin in the crypt. Initially thought to be those of a notorious clan chief nicknamed the Old Fox, they were discovered to be those of a young woman plus four others.Previously, the mausoleum and burial ground drew in a few hundred people each year but last year numbers were between 2000 and 2500 - although it could be higher as not all visitors are recorded.&nbsp&nbspWhile the burial ground is owned by Highland Council, the 17th century building is owned by the voluntary-run Wardlaw Mausoleum Trust which faces a constant challenge regarding its maintenance.Trust member Erik Lundberg said it was a technically-challenging task to carry out appropriate upkeep and repairs to the building given its age and construction.There was a problem with persistent moisture, for example, caused by an adjoining burial area having a higher ground level than the mausoleum."The trust was set up in the early 1990s to take over the ownership and eventual restoration of the mausoleum and that was done in 1998," Mt Lundberg said."The only income the trust gets is from donations from visitors. When you don&rsquot get as many visitors as you would like especially up until recent years, you don&rsquot really have the funds to maintain the building as you would like."He explained that the building should undergo lime rendering to the outside and lime plastering to the inside plus coats of lime wash about every five years. But it is now 20 years since such work was carried out.&nbsp&nbsp"There should be a rolling programme of things to keep a building in good order especially if it is historical," he said."But with a lack of funds we have only been able to do simple things. There is a backlog of things which need to be done."The trust is raising the mausoleum' profile online and via social media thanks to the volunteer efforts of Mr Lundberg' student daughter who studies away from home.&nbsp&nbsp&nbsp&nbsp&nbsp&nbsp&nbspBut Mr Lundberg believes much more could be done with the development of the website and an app."We really need to have better interpretation of the building," he said. "At Culloden Battlefield, they have got display panels and we would like something similar for the mausoleum."He estimated the cost of renovation and improved interpretation would come to about &pound100,000."It is going to need a serious fundraising exercise," he said.&nbsp&nbsp&nbsp&nbsp&nbsp&nbsp&nbsp&nbsp&nbsp&nbsp&nbspHe welcomed the recent award of &pound36,000 from Highland Council for work in the graveyard including urgent repairs to structures such as perimeter walls and gravestones.It also includes the removal of several trees including six dead elms. Several other trees were in danager of damaging gravestones.Tuesday 14 Aug 2018 4:36 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Provisional plans for Cradlehall put on hold
story: &nbspCOUNCILLORS have rejected planning permission in principle for new commercial units at Cradlehall Court in Inverness.Proposals were spelled out on Wednesday to the south planning committee for "potential use", with a proposed new access from Caulfield Road. The applicant Sean Kelly has not yet outlined specific commercial uses.Committee members were steered by officers to refuse the proposal within the existing "neighbourhood centre" primarily because it was felt it would not blend in with the local environment.Area planning manager Nicola Drummond said there was "no proven need" for additional retail provision at the city location.There was support for it from the local community council but planners also felt there was "little or no regard to meaningful integration by design with the existing neighbourhood centre".Conservative group leader and Inverness South councillor Andrew Jarvie edged towards a motion to challenge refusal of the proposal.He pointed out that traffic-calming mitigation measures, considered as part of the process, would improve public safety in an area that he said was prone to a high rate of speeding.Councillor Jarvie ultimately opted not to press for a vote but added: "I&rsquod be happy to see this development come back as a full application knowing there' the demand and desire for it in the community."Mr Kelly declined to comment after the committee meeting.Tuesday 14 Aug 2018 4:36 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: Survey gives thumbs down to airport name change
story: &nbspTHE idea of a change of name for Inverness Airport has been overwhelmingly rejected.Highlands and Islands Airports Ltd (Hial), the owners of the city airport, had asked for views on changing it to Inverness Loch Ness, given the popularity of Nessie as a worldwide brand.Of more than 900 people who responded to the online poll, 88 per cent came out against it, with just 112 people in favour.Some believed the change would be misleading, as the airport is closer to Nairn than to Loch Ness.One respondent, Simon Varwell, said: "I appreciate Loch Ness is a major brand but so is, for instance, the Great Glen or the Cairngorms. Inverness is a simple and effective brand in itself."Inverness Chamber of Commerce chief executive Stewart Nicol, however, backed the idea."We&rsquove had another significant tourism season and we should do anything we can to promote Inverness as an international destination," he said.Hial defended its decision to run the poll.A spokesman said: "The idea of including Loch Ness in the name of Inverness Airport has been raised in the past and we thought it would be interesting to gauge the response from the public."At this stage there are no plans to take the idea further than asking people their thoughts."Tuesday 14 Aug 2018 4:36 AM&nbsp&nbsp

title: inspectors aberdeen kids club is like a home from home
story: An Aberdeen out-of-school club has been praised for being like a home from home for children.Inspectors from the Care Inspectorate watchdog visited Oldmachar Out of School Club, at Forehill Primary School, Bridge of Don, on July 16 and have now published their inspection report.They rated the club, which looks after up to 50 children at a time, “very good” for care, support, management and leadership – the second best of six possible ratings.“The club provided a welcoming, professional, yet home-from-home service for children and families,” said the report.It added: “Children and staff shared warm and respectful relationships and clearly enjoyed one another’s company.”One parent told inspectors: “I have two very happy children using this service.“My children are always happy to go and always annoyed if I collect them too early as they are busy playing.”

title: latest section of awpr set to open
story: A new section of the Aberdeen bypass is set to open this week.Scottish Government Secretary for Transport Michael Matheson made the announcement today that the Balmedie to Tipperty section of the £745 million project is taking a step closer to completion.The 7.5-mile stretch will be open to drivers in time for the morning rush hour on Wednesday.Transport Scotland hopes that the new section, which represents a fifth of the whole project, will improve safety and journey time between Balmedie and Tipperty.Mr Matheson said: &#8220We said we would open new sections of road as soon as they were ready for traffic and we are delivering on that commitment.&#8220This will be very welcome news to the local community, road users and businesses who have been so patient while these works have been on-going.&#8220We thank them for their continued support.“Every day tens of thousands of drivers will now begin to reap the benefits of this section of new road, which was originally a separate project to the AWPR, through enhanced safety, reduced congestion, improved journey time reliability, and safer access to local areas and the wider public network.“The full benefits of this huge project will be realised when the AWPR/B-T opens in late Autumn 2018.&#8220Our investment in this project is expected to bring in an additional £6 billion to the north-east economy and create around 14,000 jobs over the next 30 years.”Aberdeenshire Council leader Jim Gifford said: &#8220It is very pleasing to see the Balmedie-Tipperty section of the route fully open to traffic.As well as improving access to communities along the A90, the development brings some welcome additional capacity on what is an important route for commuting and business traffic.“It also brings us a step closer to the conclusion of the AWPR/B-T project and it is now even easier to visualise how the development will improve access and journey times across the north-east.”The project is still slated for an Autumn completion, following a series of delays caused by bad weather and the collapse of Carillion, a contractor on the project.

title: ski slopes to close for repairs
story: A dry ski slope is due to close for repairs following the summer season.The Snowflex Alpine and nursery slopes, at Aberdeen Snowsports in Garthdee, is due to shut for two stints of repair and cleaning.The first closure of the alpine slope will take place between August 20 and September 2.As a result of the closure, all snowboarding lessons will be cancelled, restarting again on September 3.The nursery slope will then be closed for the same works on September 3 through to September 9.Classes will resume on the nursery slope on September 10.Customers who have purchased the “Learn it” pass, to gain access to lessons, will have any cancelled classes reimbursed.Open sessions “Love it” and “Live it” passes will not be available during the closures.Any inquiries about the closure of the slopes can be sent to program@aberdeensnowsports

title: trek the great wall to boost childrens charity
story: Members of the public are being encouraged to sign up to trek the length of the Great Wall of China – virtually.The Archie Foundation, which is based in Aberdeen, runs an annual fundraising competition – with this year marking the eighth time the initiative has run.Throughout September, people can take on the month-long trek, with all money raised going towards supporting children in hospital.Participants are asked to sign up online for the challenge through the Archie’s Challenge website.Steps are tracked using either a pedometer, Fitbit or similar piece of equipment.The challenge will see a 175-mile section of the Great Wall of China taken on, as the entire wall is more than 13,000 miles long.In reality it is not possible to walk the entire length, as much of it is in ruins, but it’s estimated to take around 177 days to complete in its entirety.To complete the section, people will be asked to walk a minimum of 13,700 steps per day.While taking part, people are also encouraged to raise money for the children’s charity.The person who raises the most money at the end of the challenge will win a trip to China, so that they can walk a section of the wall in person.Other prizes up for grabs include trophies, a certificate, t-shirts and a goodie bag, depending on how much money is raised.Last year’s winner Colleen Hutchison raised £1191.21.She said: “When I set up the online fundraiser I didn’t expect to raise the amount I did.“I still can’t quite believe I am going all the way to China to walk on the wall.“I am very excited and delighted my sisters will be with me to share this amazing experience.“Signing up for the virtual trek in 2017 has led to far more than I ever expected.“All I can say is if I can, anyone can, so get signed up for this year’s challenge and maybe you can be as lucky as me and help an amazing charity at the same time.”To sign up for the Archie Foundation challenge, visit: www.archieschallenge.org.uk

title: letters to the editor week 30
story: Colin CameronUpdated: 30/07/18, 9:27 amLikeGoogle +1TweetEmailWant to read more?We value our content and our journalists, so to get full access to all your local news updated 7-days-a-week – PLUS an e-edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser – subscribe today for as little as 56 pence per week.Sir,As usual with Councillor Redman, he was so desperate to berate the SNP in his letter published in the July 20 edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser that he is unable to see the hypocrisy of his own stance.He talks of &#8216stealth taxes&#8217 hitting &#8216the most vulnerable people in our society, particularly elderly people living alone&#8217.His accusation of &#8216taking their eye off the day job&#8217 begs the question as to where he was when the Tory government introduced its bedroom tax &#8211 a tax on those who needed an extra room for live-in carers, a tax on grandparents who wanted to have their grandchildren to stay for weekends and at holiday times a tax on widows with sons and daughters in the armed forces expected to sleep on a sofa when home on leave.A disgraceful tax which the SNP government abolishedDavid Hay, MinardSir,It was superb to once again meet up with locals in Whitehouse and across west Kintyre. As well as hearing about numerous problems with local road repairs I also listen to concerns about slow internet speed with some areas lagging behind others when it comes to getting access to superfast broadband.I heard similar concerns when I attended the latest West Kintyre Community Council meeting. As ever, I will looking into every issue brought to my attention by local residents across my council ward.After travelling back to Islay I checked up on the state of road repairs across the island. Some progress has been made in many areas like the Hospital Road in Bowmore and Mansefield Road in Port Ellen. The potholes in Port Askaig that I had been telling our roads department about have been filled in.After calling and emailing around about the large and dangerous potholes at An Creagan Place in Port Charlotte, I have been informed that the road in this area is not the responsibility of Argyll and Bute Council. It belongs to ACHA, and since obtaining this information I spoke in person to the very helpful and hard-working staff at the Bowmore ACHA office and asked them to fill in these potholes.Aside from road concerns on Islay, quite a number of my fellow Ileachs have mentioned lack of bed spaces in Islay&#8217s hospital. Being an island community obviously means that transferring more and more patients to the mainland is hardly ideal.The consensus from my constituents who I have been in contact with is that the number of beds in Islay&#8217s hospital is not enough. I have contacted NHS Highland to voice my constituents anger about this situation.Cllr Alastair Redman, Isle of IslaySir,The Marine Conservation Society (MCS) is seeking volunteers to clean up Scotland’s beaches in the 25th anniversary Great British Beach Clean from September 14-17.Volunteers also record the litter they find, and this has really helped change policy and behaviours.Last year 1,588 volunteers in Scotland took part, cleaning 111 beaches in four days. A staggering 491.4 pieces of litter were found for every 100 metres cleaned, a seven per cent rise on the amount recorded during 2016&#8217s event.The fight to stop the plastic tide has only just started and we need everyone to take part now more than ever. We need the evidence from these surveys to highlight the action we all need to take for the sake of Scotland’s seas.To volunteer visit www.mcsuk.org/greatbritishbeachclean or call 01989 566017.Catherine Gemmell, MCS Scotland Conservation Officer.Sir,The Tories’ hypocrisy on MoD wages has been exposed – after it was revealed that around 220 staff in Scotland don’t receive the Real Living Wage, just days after the Tories topped up the pay of some of the best paid MoD staff.An MoD Freedom of Information response revealed that 220 staff in Scotland earn below the Real Living Wage of £8.75 an hour – yet they are not in line to receive any pay boost from their employers. The Tories’ policy is set to cost around £4 million – yet boosting the wages of those receiving less than the real living wage would cost, at most, under £400,000.This smacks of utter hypocrisy from the Tories, after their comments of recent days regarding pay for forces personnel.What the Tories are choosing to overlook is the immense benefits service personnel have living in Scotland, like free prescriptions and university tuition fees for their children.  And it’s only those earning above £33k who pay a fraction more.If they are so concerned with equality – why aren’t they ensuring that all MoD staff are paid the living wage?Boosting the incomes of the lowest paid MoD staff could cost the Tories less than a tenth of what they are spending to top up higher incomes – yet once again, for people on lower incomes they are not prepared to lift a finger.The Tories’ double standards know no bounds – it’s one rule for the elite and another for the rest.Brendan O&#8217Hara, MP for Argyll and Bute

title: the sands of time are running out
story: Dorothy H CrawfordUpdated: 02/08/18, 6:33 amLikeGoogle +1TweetEmailWant to read more?We value our content and our journalists, so to get full access to all your local news updated 7-days-a-week – PLUS an e-edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser – subscribe today for as little as 56 pence per week.Subscribe NowAncient sayings relating to sand generally highlight its abundance. In the Bible for example: ‘I will…make thy seed as the sand of the sea, which cannot be numbered for multitude.’ But despite estimates that Earth contains roughly seven quintillion, 500 quadrillion grains of sand, world stocks are running dangerously low.Chemically, sand is mostly silicon dioxide, and is non-renewable.  It is essential for manufacturing bricks, plaster, glass, microchips, and above all concrete the most popular and versatile modern building material.  Concrete accounts for 75 per cent of our demand for sand with around 20 billion tons produced globally each year.  Even so, surely there’s an almost infinite sand supply from deserts.Unfortunately not.  Sand grains come in different shapes and sizes, and while desert sand has small, smooth grains, concrete requires large, coarse-grained sand.  This is generally mined from rivers, beaches and the sea bed.  And because international control of sand mining is well-nigh impossible, sand piracy is rife, causing huge ecological damage.Recently, 24 Indonesian islands were mined to extinction, with most of the sand used for land reclamation in Singapore, the world’s largest sand importer.Our dependence on concrete is not just for new builds.  Concrete’s life expectancy is just 50-60 years, after which so-called ‘concrete creep’ allows water seepage that corrodes supporting metal structures. So more concrete is required to repair or replace old buildings.Now engineers are coming up with ingenious ideas for repairing cracked concrete, including using bacteria and fungi that produce calcium carbonate.This could heal micro-cracks but the process will be years in development, while right now the US spend around $79 billion annually on bridge and highway maintenance and there are an estimated 188 million daily trips across ‘at risk’ bridges.Many UK bridges are similarly at risk, so do we have a solution? The short answer is ‘no’, but right now the race is on to find new, more durable building materials to replace the need for sand and in so-doing preserve marine ecosystems.
